reviewText: After reading a great deal of positive reviews for this film, I added it my Blockbuster queue as soon as it had a release date. I had high hopes for the film, and it lived up to them. The special effects were cool, the action was good, the story was intriguing, and the soundtrack was very fitting. It's a good flick. Check it out.

I read these amazing reviews and rented this movie so I felt compelled to write a counterpoint despite not having finished watching the film (I do not intend to either).  This film is not...good.  The director is ambitious and has some interesting ideas however he does not have any budget, actors or a decent script.  Some of the character ideas and sets were pretty cool however they are drowned out by the wretched acting and ham-fisted dialog.  I'm not sure what the plot was because 10 minutes into the film I didn't care what the plot was, every-time one of the cardboard cutout characters spoke it hurt my brain, I lasted 25 mins then I shut it off. This is the kinda fair that a devoted Sy-fy channel watcher might suffer through but the less enthusiastic should avoid this film at all costs.

I saw Ink at a film festival in Annapolis, MD. I was unprepared for both the power and the originality of this independent film.  It is the story of a young girl who lives in a dark dangerous world where different forces having fantastic powers try to influence dreams for good or for evil. The girl is being raised by dysfunctional parents and is put into danger by a creature nicknamed, "Ink". The effects are fantastic for a film made without the benefit of traditional industry funding. The suspense and fully realized characters are the equal of any "Hollywood" film and it was the best film I have seen in years.

Ink is filled with unique, original characters and you will fall in love with the character of the little girl.  I literally could not take my eyes off the screen due to the fact that I really cared about what was going to happen to these people. This is a film I guarantee you will never forget. Don't miss it!

I hope the success of Ink propels Jamin and Kiowa Winans to make many more remarkable films.

This is a rewrite of my original review. I received several angry responses from people who were upset that I attacked the fact that there were so many shills writing in to boost the sales/rentals of the film as opposed to addressing the film itself. They were correct, so here it goes.

This movie simply is not that good. Not on any level. the acting is lousy accept for the little girl and the "story teller." the whole thing needed to be shot on film as opposed to video. Whatever moods were trying to be created just did not come across. The wardrobe stunk, and I do not know where all the "powerful images" were that some of the reviewers spoke of. There was nothing powerful in anything I saw. The characters with the screens over their faces along with the glowing eye beings were supposed to evoke (I guess) some nightmarish, horror image, but I found it only strange for strange sake.

The story was written in strokes that were way too broad. It needed much more detail everywhere. Take the "good guys." You have this band of people who first fail to protect the little girl, then have to go and rescue her. Who are they? They have no names and we don't get to know them, so when they get into their various scrapes, there's no emotional dimension to involve the audience. Then there's the pathfinder. There was some attempt to create a character here but nowhere near enough was done to flesh him out. The tape over his eyes was merely strange and didn't add anything to his character. He was, though, in the one and only good scene in the entire movie where he orchestrates a cause and effect ballet which puts "Ink" in the hospital.

The music score was OK with one piece that stuck out as being better than the rest but I'm grasping at straws here. The editing was uneven at best and poor in most parts. If you put this up against the film "Franklyn", which is not that dissimilar, you would find Franklyn excels at every level. Maybe putting an "ST" in front of this title would have suited it better.
One of the most original films I've seen in years.  With all the dreck coming out of Hollywood, how on earth did this not do huge theater business?  It's a crime.  By all means see it.

I read in Joblo that this was "absolutely one of the best movies of 2009" and I am always on the lookout for good fantasy so I had to see it.  Th trailers were great and the reviews were great, but none of them capture how good this movie is.  I watched it hoping for a good scifi flick, and ended up with tears in my eyes.  It's brilliantly edited, visually incomparable, and well acted.  It's the kind of movie you will watch multiple times and continue to uncover new elements of the story.  Yet it's still amazing on the first viewing.  Get this movie and be prepared to be confused AND entertained!  Hahah.  DEFINITELY, one of the best moves of 2009. Visually, it is stunning; with many ongoing styles, superb action sequences, an unparalleled density of shots and material, not to mention great effects!  Having said all that, it's going to be the story that blows you away!

The trailers for the film online are very, very cool, but you really have no idea what you're about to experience.  I promise you that you have never, ever seen anything like "Ink" before!  GET THIS FILM...you WILL NOT be sorry.

Skip big-budget remakes and sappy Renee Zelwegger flicks this season, and choose "Ink."

I really could go on.  This is everything good that can come from a small artistic film, which the greater entity of Hollywood will always have lacking.  It is not a canned rerererereremade idea or film, it is a piece of art, masterfully crafted by many artists working in beautiful synchrony.  There are few films out there of this calibre, or at the least they are lost in the over saturated morass of mass produced media.

... I've not seen a movie like this.  It is so dismembered I was put off at first, but I didn't give up and like an explosion run backward, it began to come together, and a more coherent story line began to show.  The scenes are very well done, for what they are, though, I couldn't decide if the protagonists are operating in a parallel reality, one of them is either having a near death experience or is already dead, or whether it is just a dream.  In any event, this is an unusual movie, the sound effects with a good headphones are startling,  Costumes and visuals are original thinking, lighting is almost a character of its own, sound already mentioned, directing is either non-existent or extraordinary -the characters completely carry their parts- and the editing stitched disparate scenes into a kind of Frankenfilm sutured with noise, flashes of light and disorientation. The acting was horribly lame and stilted, forced, and I strongly suspected that the casting director used the roster of producers to select roles.

There was one single [obvious] exception, the little girl kidnapped by the bogeyman kitted out like a sniper sans rifle: She was a good pretender, while her "colleagues" STANK.

Wow. This production is not a high-budget blockbuster, and it does not have any big names attached to it. Don't let that stop you from watching it! The grave reality of spiritual warfare...shame and redemption...worldly success and the state of your soul...The plot reveals itself like unrolling a tapestry while looking at the backside - nothing makes much sense until you finish unrolling it and turn it over, and then you are blown away.

I love this movie! This story is about rebuilding the relationship between a father and his daughter. The story is told between the real world and the subconscious/dream world. Most of the story is told from the perspective of the little girl, who loves adventure but often doesn't get time to spend with her dad. The little girls dad often works long hours and since the loss of his wife has only focused on work. At the end of the movie you are on the edge of your seat to see if daughter and dad reunite.

First off, this movie isn't for everyone. If you are a realist and don't enjoy fantasy, this isn't for you. The best analogy I can give this film is if "Pan's Labyrinth" reverberated with you then you will like this film. Keep in mind that this film used no big budget Hollywood tricks. Most of the effects are pulled off using lighting, exposure, and photographic after effects but it works. Mr. Winans, the director, uses some absolutely stunning edits. The movie and it's mood just flows. One reviewer said this is not a film to watch out of the corner of your eye with interruptions. I couldn't agree more. This is a late night film with the lights off so you can just let it wash over you and understand who the characters are and what they do. Myself, I was immersed in the first ten minutes. I won't spoil it but it is such a pleasant feeling when the seemingly disparate parts of the movie all of a sudden jumble into place. By the way, the music was great at setting the mood as well. Glad I saw it and surprised Mr Winans hasn't made a huge splash. He deserves it.....

This is my absolute FAVORITE movie of all time.  I'm a big fan of great 80's kids classics like Labyrinth, The Dark Crystal, Legend... any of the barrage of childhood "fantasy" that kept our imaginations intact- or at least, they were designed to do that.
Ink is a graduation level from that realm.  Everything important- heart- decision- rough moments- loss- has been taken to a new place where CHOICE becomes applicable.
I've never seen anyone explain the outer workings of reality quite as well or as beautifully as the Winans do with this film.  And if you love this one as much as you SHOULD, check out "The Frame", their next film- gets even more alchemically personal with two wonderful might-be lovers chasing each other down through different realities.
Few are bold enough to explore what they do, and to my last breath I will try and tell everyone who talks of the moments or dynamics inherent in their films completely UP.  Worthy of more than that, in the long run this couple made films worthy of our attempts to LIVE OUT THESE IDEAS, concepts, and ideals.
The world would be heaven if we did.

It's also got surprisingly good fight choreography. And, for anyone concerned about it, the action while intense, is mostly cartoony/comic bookish (and not Netflix comic bookish which can actually be very violent) so I'd say it's family friendly too. If you're on the fence I'd say it's worth watching.

Honest review: A wonderful idea, a good story and poignant fairy-tale regarding the dangers of giving in to weakness and the evils of neglect and shame.  Plays on old archetypes of angels and demonic influences and how that impacts the lives of those around us.  In short, I was enraptured by the tale and wound up very moved by it.

The film overall, however, is produced at a somewhat amateur level. I think the filtering is meant to create an illusion of another world (and maybe that's why it's marketed like Sin City), but the noir effect is overused. A better choice would have been to use it transitionally I think.

Some of the cinematography is executed brilliantly and sometimes too experimentally, whereas it seems done for its sake alone and not to further the story.  But when it's shot right, it's powerful.  I would have like to have seen more color introduced, especially symbolically. For example, the weapons used, the recorder and other devices. Ah well.

Soundtrack is very good unlike most amateur productions and kept me involved even at slower points. With that said, make no mistake - some of these poor reviews (particularly about this film being slow), are from heathens who probably prefer a brainless action flick compared to what this truly is; a modern, epic fairy tale with a cerebrally emotional and artistic flair.  If that's the kind of film you like, you will look past the flaws and find, as I did, a very moving tale.

I normally shy away from dark films with disturbing images - but I thought I'd give this one a try - in part because of the high ratings, in part because of the father/daughter relationship.

Yes - this movie was dark and disturbing at times, as well as beautiful and sad and encouraging. It exemplifies how someone can believe the lie of the world's metric of success, only to realize they are working for the enemy who told them that lie.

With elements of the angelic and demonic, the afterlife, evil vs good, lie vs truth, this movie convicts the viewer about where they place their priorities in life - as humans we can so easily get caught up in our selfishness.  Often, it takes a crisis to help us realize what is truly important: love, true beauty, truth, family, healthy relationships.

As a follower of Jesus Christ, this story was a good reminder that there is a spiritual realm we cannot see, and there are angels and demons warring against one another.  The enemy is Satan, the father of lies - and his demons- who will try to deceive us with promises of success, (false) beauty, pride.

I hope that you take the time to watch this movie, disturbing at times, but eye-opening and moving.  Allow the story to help you reflect on your own life, and the choices you make.  Jesus is God, He loves you, and He wants you repent like the main character in this story, and choose Him - choose life and love.

Everything in the movie is meant to be blurry to make up for the low budget special effects and to create a dream like effect. (Think Sin City, but filmed with a very nice home camera.)  It's still grainy in many scenes, and I don't think you want to be able to see the finer details of some of the costume make up anyway (there were times I thought one of the actor's fake noses might fall off, and it was very distracting to the story line).  The movie style is definitely different from your main stream stuff.  I love indie films, but I honestly think all the 5 star review are from very artsy type of people or those interested in making films.

The tone of the movie is dark with a fantasy feel. I was hoping for something along the lines of The Labyrinth or a Tim Burton movie, but this was not it. This movie almost reminded me of live action anime/manga. Costumes were along the lines of what you'd see an average person whip up for a cosplay convention or wear to hang out at Hot Topic in the mall.  Dialogue was even limited at times. There were a lot of fight scenes, which I feel were too unbelievable and actually detracted from the movie's quality. Punches and tosses were way too choreographed and very unconvincing.  The minor bits of blood, cuts, and bruises were unrealistic and strategically placed on the actors faces to maintain their good looks. No swelling, no trickled blood, no ruined make up, no messy hair.  Just a few strategically placed cuts and a lot of skinny, overaccesorized people posing in cool fighting stances.  I just felt the fight scenes were excessive for the story and we're poorly performed in many ways.  It was like the focus was pulled away from the story line for the moment to amp up how bad-ass these actors were supposed to be.

Overall, I would only recommend this movie to someone who is really into dark, fighting style anime and who is curious to see what it would look like in live action. The editing gave a sense of the surreal and macabre that still seemed utterly believable.  Each and every actor conveyed their part as if they *were* their part.

The story lines were intricately woven and yet easily discerned.

The script was delivered with the newer and fashionable stuttered scene approach that succeeded where others have failed, not making one feel distracted or disoriented but instead feeling as if it were utterly correct for the story that was told.  Despite being so surreal the story, acting, editing and progress made complete sense.

Normally the technique of stutter jumping from present to past and point of view to point of view is veryincredibly distracting but here the director and editor made it so incredibly smooth that it seemed perfectly natural.

The protagonists and antagonists were astonishingly well portrayed with the battle between good and evil, hope and despair presented with astonishing clarity due to the editing.

The concept that hope triumphs over despair and good over evil is a welcome sign that all has not been lost to the typical dark screen writing that pervades so much of our cinematic content these days.

Yes, this movie moved me to make one of the more in depth reviews I have ever written. Despite its very dark presentation, this is a movie of an amazing journey of discovery and self sacrifice.

Everyone's entitled to their own opinion, therefore I disregard the negative reviews. Some people need a more linear, step-by-step story line, some people don't get a deeper story, or one that calls forth the emotions. Some need more "pizzazz" and CGI and fires and explosions to hold their interest. This is not "Ink". As for the person who said the positive reviews must be fake, consider the source.

I've seen this move a dozen times and it never fails to grab my interest. I associate with a few independent filmmakers and my personal opinion to them is "this should be required viewing for any independent filmmaker". This is what independent movie making is all about.

This is not a child's movie in any sense of the word. I would say it's more along the lines of young adult and older. It can go deep sometimes, but you don't stay "under" for long. There is time to come up for a breath. While it does have a certain teenager charm, it doesn't pull punches with language or strong emotional scenes. It also doesn't rely on nudity or "shock" value to carry the story. The characters are bold and stand out on their own. Each character is well-developed. There is no doubt about who's who.

Made on a small budget compared to the multi-million dollar movies, the actors are three-dimensional. never flat, not cliche, and believable.

Violence. There are plenty of fight scenes, a touch of blood, but no gore. The choreography is well done and not over-the-top. Then there is a bit of comic relief to offset the darkness, but again this isn't slapstick or frat-boy humor. It's more like a little sweet to offset the bitter, just to keep it palatable.

There is a definite "spiritual" essence to the movie but no specific religious slant.

There was at least six months pre-production, makeup tests, combative training and choreography. The credits list a massive cast including extras. Most of the scenes are set in established locations; this budget didn't allow for massive sound stage constructions and it doesn't need it. There is no doubt the work behind the work was extreme.

Finally, there is the storyline itself. It is superbly written. It is self-explanatory and if one pays attention the story rounds out quite clearly (no spoilers, no not one).

Over all I highly recommend "Ink", not for the whole family, but for serious students of movie making, viewers looking for more than the Hollywood hype, and anyone who can appreciate the work that goes into making independent movies.

I liked the second act of Ink a lot because it was science fiction and it was a bit like the Adjustment Bureau or some Twilight Zone episode. This is an independent film by Jamin Winans. This is one of two films I've seen by this director and both are in the same vein of dark fantasy. Much of this film is symbolic and time doesn't pass in a linear way all the time. In fact, its greatest weakness seems to be a by-product of this technique. Namely, the movie is about a half hour too long and suffers from redundant flashback and dream scenes, as well as not being edited economically to begin with. Toward the end of the film, I was saying to myself, "Ok, ok, I get it already..." and was past ready for things to ultimately sort themselves out. The basic elements of the film revolve around a good v evil struggle, complete with (what amounts to) good and bad angels who affect/inspire the sleeping dreams of we humans. There is a renegade evil being (incubus) who creates a snafu with the whole process and it must be stopped to save the life of a little girl. Winans is extremely competent with the visuals as well as effects here and creates a convincing alternate reality. I enjoy indie films like this that involve non-conventional film making techniques and storytelling, but this one gets to be self indulgent after a point. Winans' subsequent film, Frame, is a bit tighter, albeit equally strange. If you're looking for something decidedly out of the ordinary and have about 2 hours to spend, I'd recommend this. However, if you want to choose between Ink and Frame, I'd recommend Frame.

The plot concerns the eternal fight between good guys (who give us good dreams and encouragement) and the bad guys (who give us nightmares and despair) and a little girl caught in the middle. Mix this with excellent cinematography, production design, editing, effects, surprisingly exciting fight scenes and a strong cast led by Christopher Soren Kelly and 10 year old Quinn Hunchar and you have a rare gem! Tom B. in Virginia - As a male, sci-fi / fantasy fan of many decades... this movie is a disappointment to me.  I liked the imagery and consider the cinematography, lighting and sound to be first rate.  Jamin Winans (male) is both writer and director but Ink is so strongly estrogen-driven that you might be inclined to conclude that Winans was channeling an indignant feminist or a young mother who was angry at her former husband.

Jessica Duffy's performance was torturous for me to endure.  She plays her part as a smug mother-warrior who expresses both compassion and hostility (at her male competitor) in almost the same breath.  Talk about contradictory motivations!  Her character is portrayed as so superior to this man that she is even willing to sacrifice herself for the 'greater good.'  Hallelujah!  Women are great!  Let's all genuflect.

The 'greater good' is achieved by shaking (literally) good sense into a prideful man in order to help him get his priorities straight and to put his love for his only child above all else.  Okay, that's an altruistic foundation for a plot but the undercurrent, incited by the mother-warrior's smugness, is that men cannot achieve such a goal without the help of women because men are selfish, single-minded, don't know what is important in life AND men can't help but make women suffer.  The latter is further enforced by the fact that the bad guys are just that... all guys!  Give me a break!

The film's other warriors (for the 'good side') range from being conflicted to clueless.  One of them argrily expresses her negative beliefs, albeit unfounded, about one of her team members.  This display of projection, born from ignorance, muddles earlier implications that these warriors are near-divine.  Consequently, a higher purpose becomes secondary as they morph into something akin to a pugnacious band of cohorts, just out of a kendo class, looking for guys in black dress to beat up.

I had to stop and start my viewing of Ink four times (watching other movies in-between) in order to get through it.  I would have given up about a third of the way through but I was hoping something would happen to redeem this movie (no luck).

Maybe Winans should chum-it-up with Alex Proyas (Dark City, The Crow) and get some pointers on how to make a really good sci-fi / fantasy movie.  Nevertheless, Ink is an indie film and I give Winans an 'A' for effort and hope to see other movies from him in the future with less gender-bias.

I believe Ink is more likely to appeal to girls and women, in general, and to those boys and men who are more strongly influenced by imagery than by substance.  Imaginative imagery in movies is great but, in my view, in order to rise above the fray such imagery has to be accompanied by at least one complex and believable character (only one character, Chris Kelly's, is given any depth at all) and with all characters being driven by understandable and non-contradictory motives.

INK is a film I heard about while watching a review for another film, THE FRAME, and so I watched it based on the reviewer's admiration for it. Now having seen it, I must say that it is visually creative and unique, but it also suffers from iffy acting and a predictable story. The basic plot is that a wandering soul, or Drifter, captures the soul of a young girl in hopes that he will be accepted into a cabal of nightmare creators known as Incubi. Meanwhile her father, who is having problems of his own, has to find a way to reconnect with and save her. One thing that really recommends this movie is the mythology that it sets up which is unlike anything I've ever seen before. There are two different realms, the real world and the dream world, and in the dream world there are several different kinds of beings. There are Storytellers who give people dreams, Incubi who give people nightmares, Pathfinders who are able to affect the course of people's lives, and Drifters who are the wandering souls of people who have died. None of this is really explained in depth, but is shown first and then explained a little bit later in case you missed it. If there is one problem, it's that the narrative is a bit exposition-heavy in parts, but never for very long. My favorite part of the film was the visual style, though. There was an ethereal, chiaroscuro-esque filter that lent the film a dreamlike quality. They were also creative with the visual effects and editing which provided a disorienting effect as you try to figure out what's going on. Still, some of the editing wasn't that great, especially in some fight scenes between the Storytellers and Incubi. It was in those scenes that the film's low budget really came to the fore. However, the biggest drawback to this film is the acting. It was downright weird at times and felt a little hammy/stage-like, so much so that it kind of took me out of the story. Overall, the end result was a bit of a mixed bag. On one hand, you have the strong visual style, but then you also have the (at times) weak and obvious writing coupled with some sub-par acting. Still, if this film is any indication its director is one to look out for, and for what it's worth this was an interesting watch.

"Ink" is a creative juggernaut.  I mean it...I was floored by how this film did such a great job at what so many multi-million dollar movies fail to do: use every iota of their power to move their audiences.

No million dollar cast, no amazing special effects (and for a fantasy movie at that!), no ad campaign whatsoever, and still I sat there stunned by how well this minor little project from an independent film company (Double Edge Films) worked.

"Ink" is a movie that I don't want to tell you too much about, but I will give you the barest of bones: while there are gentle spirits who slip into our bedrooms at night to give us pleasant dreams, a lovely child has an ugly beast slip into her room to steal her away.  For reasons as yet unknown, perhaps even to the spirits themselves, the spirits decide to save this girl, and the movie depicts this struggle.  I should also say that, while a child is central to the work, it is not a work necessarily FOR children.

I am sure I have done this movie a disservice to describe its plot in such generalities, but I think the greater disservice would be to rob you of the pleasure at peeling away the layers of this clever, brilliant work.  I was certainly puzzled often as this film moved along its path, and as with many mysterious, "intellectual" movies I wondered if I would get it, and if the film would be worth the effort.  Believe me, YOU will, and IT will.  In spades.

(Incidentally, I placed the word "intellectual" in quotes in the paragraph above because, while I think it is an intellectual film, I don't want you to think it is one of those heady films for nerds.  I think A LOT of people would like this movie.)

And while this is indeed a largely metaphoric work, you don't have to be an English major to follow it.  I do feel I need (and want) to see it again, as there are layers of this onion that I will have a more enhanced enjoyment of on my next viewing.  But I think the beauty of "Ink" is in -- after breathing "Wow!" at the end of your first viewing -- getting together and talking about it with someone.  It's really a bright, bright piece of film making.

And to get back to those effects: without cheapening anything, director, writer and co-producer Jamin Winans (who did the editing AND music as well!) deserves much credit for getting inexpensive techniques to do so much.  This is no "Our Town" where the people lie on the floor to depict graves or climb a step stool to go upstairs.  But with simply "Pop!"-ing people into or out of a shot (a technique available to cinematographers since Chaplin), or using lighting, or costumes, or even putting a distorting pane of glass in front of glass in front of some characters' faces, you'll right away feel you're in a whole different level of the world.  It really works, and absolutely doesn't come off as cheap.

As with the rest of the film, the actors are first rate.  I've often wondered why we always dote on placing the same elite group of actors in all the films we see, and this is good evidence for not following that route.  Chris Kelly, Jessica Duffy, Jeremy Make...these are names we should be hearing about much more than we are.  They are terrific in their roles and I was surprised to find that none of them have yet been in any major film.  They, like everything else in this fine movie, work wonderfully.

If you like smart cinema that works on a variety of levels, you'll love "Ink."  See it, and spread the word around.

Ink (Jamin Winans, 2009) There is a sense, from the very opening sequence, of pure, absolute wrongness about Ink, the second feature from director Jamin Winans (11:59). It sounds, from the various descriptions one finds around the web, like a family film, though not necessarily a children's film (the closest analogue I had in my head, before I started watching, was Paperhouse). But then you get to that opening sequence, where John (Chris Kelly, returning from 11:59) comes storming out of an office building, throws himself into his car, and begins cursing a blue streak at the top of his lungs while driving off at high speed in midtown traffic, and okay, this is not a film for kids at all, eh? And yet, the basic premise of the film is still right in that young-adult-fantasy niche: Emma (terminally cute Quinn Hunchar in her first screen appearance), John's estranged eight-year-old daughter, has her soul stolen by Ink, a demon who inahbits a parallel universe. But I'm getting well ahead of myself. Plot: There is a universe parallel to ours, but whose denizens interact with us constantly. On one side we have the Storytellers, who come into our world at night, often dressed in the height of eighties fashion, and bring us dreams. On the other side are the Incubi, who wear a lot of pleather and very cool visors, and who are responsible for bringing us nightmares. Ink (short, of course, for Incubus) is a wannabe-dark soul who is trying to find a perfect gift to bring the leader of the Incubi in order to get himself a promotion (and cooler threads). He chooses the soul of Emma (Hunchar) and abducts it; in our world, she goes into a coma and no one can figure out why. Her grandparents, who wrested custody of her from John after their daughter died (we find out how somewhat later in the film), try to reach out to John, who started out selling junk bonds in a boiler room and is now a multi-millionaire executive, to come and be with his daughter. He throws the bitter words they told him during the court battle (specifically, "you no longer have a daughter") back in his face and escorts them out of the office while on the verge of a deal that could allow him to retire in this thirties. But beneath the quotidian veneer, the storytellers and the incubi are fighting for control of Emma's soul, and Allel (Skills Like This' Jennifer Batter), Emma's storyteller, ropes in a couple of her pals, Sarah (Hidden Lives' Shelby Malone) and Gabe (The New Republic's Eme Ikuwakor), and hires a pathfinder, Jacob (Suburban's Jeremy Make), to see if there are any...alternative options for getting Emma's soul from Ink before he can turn it over. But other forces are at work here, as well: Liev (The Inner Room's Jessica Duffy), who is either the leader of the storytellers or just a legendarily powerful one (that point is never made clear), has also taken an interest in this fight, and moves to protect Emma in her own way as well. Meanwhile, the Incubi are amassing their defenses, including sending one of their own (Troy Garner in his first feature appearance) to shadow John 24/7, a move made only in the most extreme circumstances... The best thing about Ink, by far, is the care that went into the worldbuilding here. Winans, who also wrote the screenplay, obviously put tremendous thought into the storytellers, the incubi, and how their world interacts with ours. Just based on the ease of the flow there, Winans probably came up with hundreds of little details that never made it into the story, but colored his perceptions of how these worlds interact. That's a must with worldbuilding, and every author worth his salt knows it, but it's rare to find in movies. It really adds to the atmosphere here. The worst thing about it is that the fragmenting of the movie's timeline is handled badly. I don't know whether I'm just watching more movies that do this nowadays or whether it's becoming more common for filmmakers to try and pull off these sorts of time stunts in the post-Memento world, but very few people seem to be able to do them right, even in movies I otherwise adore. The most common question by far on the IMDB board for this movie is "what the hell happened in the last scene?", and I admit, I jaunted over there after I finished watching the movie to see if my interpretation of what I'd just seen was right. (According to the prevailing wisdom, it wasn't, and I get the arguments made for the prevailing wisdom--but I still think my alternate explanation of the end makes as much sense given the clues sprinkled throughout the movie.) Sitting in the middle is that overweening sense of wrongness I alluded to right at the very beginning of this review. The whole childlike-sense-of-wonder thing is really, really cool, and I appreciate that Winans was--I assume--trying to bring that into a more adult-themed movie. The problem is, it's not an adult-themed movie, is a kid- (or young-adult)-themed movie that attempts to prove its "adultness" solely through the use of what is euphemistically termed as "adult language" in the MPAA's system. Looked at as a YA fantasy, it's complex, inviting, and at times probably inappropriate (again, because of the language). Looked at as an adult fantasy film, it's somewhat less. It tries to have its feet in two different worlds, much the way its supernatural characters do, but the film itself is far less adept at bridging them. Still, it's worth watching, and there is a gem hidden under these rags. You can see a good deal of it at times as you watch this movie. ***

This movie is absolutely amazing. The story is amazing. The originality is amazing. Everything in this movie is amazing. For such a low-budget, under-the-radar film, this one will blow you out of the water. You NEED to see this!!!!!

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. Although some of the performances from supporting actors weren't up to par at times, the main character, Ink, was outstanding! The story line really held my interest...Seeing into the alternate world and how those in it affected "reality". This is one I will add to my DvD collection.

I've lost track of how many copies I've purchased, and most of my friends aren't into "scary" movies, but to quote the famous Miami-based photographer David Vance "if Bernard was kind enough to get this for us, then let's watch it." I know he's watched it at least twice. I've lost track of how many times I've watched it, and my other famous photographer buddy, Shamus Fatzinger of DC said they'd sat down and started watching, but were too tired to finish it, and they knew it was a movie which would command their attention. I can't say enough about this movie, but J. Winans wrote it, directed it, and scored it...and scored a home run along the way. If you want to see a brilliantly filmed adult fairy tale, it's "ink" - and it has NOTHING to do with tattoos. Achingly beautiful along the way with a touch of science fiction, you won't get the full impact until you have watched it to the end. And when you find out "the secret" you'll want to start watching it all over again. Pick up the original soundtrack while you're at it. It's so much more relaxing than white noise and if you leave it on when you sleep, just under your regular audio range, it'll score many a dream, it's that great. Imagine being lulled to sleep by a soundtrack which will lead you somewhere during your slumber. I can't say enough about "ink." J Winans is a genius. A Fn genius with the pen, the camera, and musical instruments. Help support a true artist and BUY THIS FILM. If you REALLY want to surprise yourself, don't look at any of the trailers, and don't read about the storyline. Buy it, prepare yourself for something special, and just watch it. And it's even more meaningful if you watch it with someone you love, but my greyhound wasn't interested. But he kept me warm throughout. BUY ink AND WATCH IT! Catch the fever!

Bought the film based on reviews and the trailer.  I was not disappointed as this is the best film I have seen in a decade.  The story, cinematography, effects, lighting, music, acting .... All are exceptional.  A rare film in this day of mediocrity.

One of my friends called me up and told me 'You gotta watch INK as soon as possible!' I had never heard of this movie.  Its 2011 and this movie was made 2 years ago.  I never knew it existed.  So I go online and watched it.

It is one of the most creative, beautifully written and well acted movies I have ever seen and the soundtrack is just beautiful as well.  The story is amazing and the effects are fantastic.  I have read the 1 star reviews and I can only conclude that some people just don't get this movie.  Its dream like sequences are well done.  The bad guys are creepy with their glass face plates and you find yourself feeling the struggles of the good guys as you watch the story unfold till the very end.

This is a must own movie.  Its cinematic brilliance and its such a shame this movie has gone unnoticed all this time.  But don't take my word for it.  I feel as strongly for my 5 star review just as the 1 star reviews feel strongly for theirs.

This movie popped up in my "recommended list". It sounded interesting so I bought it and just watched it last night. I found it very entertaining and engaging. It has an interesting premise (which you can look up) but I recommend watching the movie.
Very interesting movie, dark in visuals, dark in initial circumstances, but in the end, enlightening and inspiring.  Different movie, definitely.

I came cross this hidden jewel on Netflix. I wasn't hoping for much but after I started watching it, I knew this was going to be one of those moives I loved. Everything about this moive is done well from the editing, acting and music. If you are looking for a good story that you can sit down and watch a few times and find something esle new every time you watch it, this is the movie. I also recommend the soundtrack.

The positive reviews must come from family and people that were involved in the production...or possibly the reviews are from the distribution company...save your money but most importantly save your time...

I'd recommend it solely because it's fairly original.

I really wanted to like this movie more then I did. Bad acting, bad writing, bad editing, bad effects, even for an indie movie. Bad pacing.

But, at least it's original and that's saying something in this day and age when most movies are a minor variation on some over told story.
Made me laugh and cry. Liked it initially, but after a couple of watches the plot flowed more nicely in my mind. Great visuals.

Ink use of a fantasy vehicle leaves much for the imagination to fill in while weaving together very simply conventional human themes that the viewer can connect with easily.
Comparisons can be made to the Matrix trilogy but where that monstrosity left flawed and tenuous connections to anything approaching reality, Ink nails them with intellectual and emotional clarity.

There is room for criticism, mostly due to the low budget stripping down wardrobes, make up.  The visual effects are clever and well orchestrated even if they draw thin.  During the first few minutes, I woke up from my shell of skepticism to allow myself to 'buy into' the films limitations to let this actors and directors take me for their trip... if you do so, you will be glad to join the many who have found this a bit rough of a gem to be a refreshing experience.

One of the best independent films imo. One of the better films at any budget. ..which puts it way up there.
Beautiful, original, touching. An excellent story well told, with instantly lovable characters. A mind bender in the style of "Dark City" and "Nine".

Now, I'm no professional film critic.  I don't have any qualifications except a love for quality films.  But this is, without question, one of my top five movies that I've seen.
Yes, the quality of filming is low, and it lacks any recognizable star power, but these things actually endear the movie to its audience.  We are able to connect with the characters in a fuller way.
The thoroughness of the mythology this film establishes in such a short span of time is impressive.  It takes an experience many of us share, our vivid dreams, and skews it beautifully into a great supernatural conflict.
The characters are engrossing and original (especially the character of the blind Jacob), and anyone who can watch this film without falling for the extreme child-cuteness levels Quinn Hunchar probably needs the lesson of this tale more than they know.
Don't be fooled, this is definitely a morality tale - it's meant to teach a lesson.  But it does it in such an open way without sacrificing the element of story that the audience comes away without feeling preached at.

I could go on and on, but let me summarize by saying again that this is a great film.  It deserves your viewership.

This movie is horrible. I suspect a lot of the positive reviews come from people who either are involved with the film or close to those folks -- or possibly from people paid to write positive reviews. Or perhaps, they were on drugs while they watched it.

I have no problem with less structured films. That's the beauty of independent stuff. But this film had a very thin plot and terrible actors. It paid no attention to character development -- at all. The best acting came from a very young girl - and I'm sure I'm being generous to her because of her age and cuteness.

The cinematography is horrendous. It looks like it was filmed with a webcam. The director looks like he tossed in elements just to make the film underground. AVOID THIS MOVIE!!!

One of the worst science fiction/fantasy movies of recent memory.  The story is almost completely incomprehensible, the characterizations nil, the cinematography overblown and amateurish at best.  It's like watching a film school student who has been given too much money for their first feature blow their budget without having any concept of how to tell a story. It is hoped that the adorable lead actress, little Quinn Hunchar, can recover from this travesty and have a future in the business. For everyone else involved, the less we see or hear from them, the better off we all will be.

Ink blew me away. The depth and layering of the characters and of each scene is phenomenal. It is a raw and honest look at the human condition. Its a spiritual movie but not a religious movie. It just about the human heart and it sucked me in and didn't let me go. The ending was for me a bit of a surprise- and I'm seldom surprised by endings. There are no real words to describe the movie because it is not an intellectual mind movie but more of a visceral experiential movie. The music, photography and etc (not just the plot) are quite important in creating this. Seriously, you just have to experience this movie. Words cant do it justice.

A touch of family drama. A dash of martial arts. I pinch of fantasy. Mixing them all together would seem like trying to mix oil, water, and sand, but instead we get an esthetic, personal approach to independent film that only Ink can bring. With ethereal lighting, a more-than-decent script, and authentic acting, Ink dazzles the eye with dream-like cinematography, touches the heart with endearing characters, and provokes the soul with themes of redemption from shame and wretchedness fashioned for an audience who appreciates art in film as well as entertainment.

When the world falls asleep, the forces of good and evil wage war against each other. The stakes; human souls. The battlefield; their dreams. As the two sides travel around giving out their dreams and nightmares, a mysterious drifter known as Ink abducts the soul of a young girl in hopes to barter her for a place in the Incubi, the assembly of evil responsible for the nightmares. Meanwhile, in the natural world a businessman's family life takes a downward spiral at the death of his wife, requiring a miracle in a most unexpected form to reunite him with his daughter and in-laws.

From the beginning of the film, the viewer gets thrown into a dual plot line of interpersonal conflict with little to no exposition of how the fantasy world operates. This is a plus for viewers who enjoy thinking and putting things together. Be advised, this is not a movie to watch if you're looking for mindless entertainment. The film assumes an intelligent audience.

With the film's low budget, Ink does not have the fancy CGI or special effects of Hollywood, so one could critique the simplicity of the good and evil beings and their worlds. But what lacks in special effects is made up for in creativity as the camera shots are more about the quality of the story rather than quality of the action. Parents, use discretion for younger audiences. Although there is absolutely no sexual content, drug use, or bloody violence, Ink is rated R for language. There are also elements that may frighten children, such as some nightmare sequences and the appearance of the Incubi who give out the nightmares. The rest of the movie would probably pass for PG material.
Cool movie.  Good message.  I was looking for more movies like "Mirror Mask" and this came up so I gave it a shot and really like it.

One of the biggest benefits of the digital revolution is that the cheap price of computing power and computing memory has allowed small companies to produce top-notch movies with quality audio and visual effects.  All one needs is a good script and believable acting.  Recent examples include MirrorMask, Dark Portals, and now this emotional drama called Ink.  The title of the movie refers to its central antagonist, a man-like creature that moves back and forth between many worlds, one of which is our dreams.  The story itself is a blend of tragedy, drama, action, and suspense, all centered around the conquest of love over greed, selflessness over selfishness, and redemption.  For the insightful viewer, one can ascertain the antagonist's true origins around the middle of the movie.  But for everyone, this is a great movie, a very original plot and great execution of its storyline.

I'm not surprised by the number of bad reviews this movie got.  It seems to be epidemic in the reviews I see here on Amazon.  If you're every wondering how seriously to take a reviews just check the other reviews an individual has written and sometimes you'll see a pattern that might help you make up your mind if a film is for you.

This wasn't so much a movie in my mind as just a really well told story.  It reminded me of the Firefly series with regard to the quality of acting and dialog.  The actors are really comfortable in their characters, which is what makes any story real.  This isn't something I would let my kids see, at least not until they were in their early teens.  This isn't for kids, it's a story that parents should watch, or anyone who may be a parent soon.  Life gets strangely tougher and tougher the older we get, and it's easy to lose our way in the perceived complexities.  This story is about a father who loses his way after dealing with tragedies and unhappiness in his life, and how the kernels of goodness in him help him to come back from edge of true destruction.  Yes, the language is realistic for people going through tough times, and yes there is some fighting (actually underplayed I though for how well those scenes were choreographed), but the interactions between the Storyteller, the little girl, and Ink are what make the story.

I'm an former straight-leg infantry soldier (for those of you who know what that means) who grew up in the deserts of Nevada, I have an awesome wife, two young children, and a busy work life.  I've seen some life; and as simple as this story is, it brought tears to my eyes, and was one more nudge back towards remembering what's important in life.  If you could use a little of that, I highly recommend this story.  Good luck all you travelers out there...

I read the good reviews for this movie and was excited to rent it on Amazon. We like independent films and their, often, unique storylines. Somehow, though, none of the reviewers mentioned all of the cursing. The first words uttered as the movie starts are a bunch of F-bombs yelled by a driver. This actually looked like a good movie idea, and we didn't care that the film is not high-quality. But the gratuitous cursing totally ruins any other good efforts, as far as this reviewer is concerned.

Whilst the indie movie trend has gotten bigger and trendier over the past couple decades, low budget movies tend to stick with Dramas, Comedies and Romances. Without big budgets, you can't compete with James Cameron and Michael Bay movies head-on with a fraction of the production values.

There is always a major risk factor in making an indie movie with heavy special effects. When competing with Industrial Light and Magic and 9-digit budgets, it is difficult to make fantastic or sci-fi effects that the average moviegoer can take seriously. In this, Ink is ambitious, and mostly succeeds. Although the color filter and bloom effect are cranked to extreme in several scenes, there are many unique and interesting effects in this movie that are fun to watch.

There are several characters who are played woodenly by actors, and the focus of the movie isn't always clear (for about two thirds of the movie, it is difficult to discern who the actual protagonist is), but with a few clever plot twists and bends in the trail, Ink ends on an enlightening note and is a perfect example of how a low-budget indie movie can tackle the sci-fi and fantasy genres with a little love and dedication.

Overall, without spoiling any of the plot, I recommend this movie to anyone who appreciates a film in which its makers' limited funding didn't stop them from crafting their dream project.

Ink is a very strange movie that is enjoyable just for that fact.  It centers around a little girl (Emma) who is stolen from her bed (whilst sleeping) and left comatose despite the best efforts of protectors - Story Tellers - who spend the nights keeping sleepers safe.

Her father (John) is at once uncomfortable with his role as a parent and attempting very hard to be there for his daughter.  It is almost painful to watch the way he interacts with his daughter, coworkers, and himself.  The way that he handles his life is perhaps so painful because it shows the darker natures of our own being.  He is not a terrible man, nor is he a good man, and his progression throughout the film is inspiring.  Even the way he copes with his pain is difficult and hard to comprehend.

Our young heroine / captive is delightfully imaginative and elegantly strange.  Unlike most little girls who spend their lives playing with dolls in the tea party variety she is a dedicated tomboy, and endearing for it.  She seems to understand with the coy intuitiveness of a child precisely how to interact with those around her.

The Story Tellers dedicated to our perfection and peace during the time of sleeping are both strangely detached and overly loving.  They exemplify the roles of protectors very well, trying to remain above situations and still maintain a compassion for those they protect.

Ink is a frightening fellow because of his entire desire to belong which is echoed by the other characters in the film.  His desperation is palpable throughout the movie.  Without revealing plot, the twist of the ending - or rather its resolution - is both heartening and touching.

The dream sequences of the movie, in fact, the entire movie is incredibly interestingly filmed.  It is both pleasant and delightfully odd.  The effects of the cameas are both heightening to the overall eery and always dreamlike qualities of the film and distracting.  The film cuts around a lot as we learn about Jacob, John, Emma, and the other characters.  While some of the images and presentations of characters can be grating they are acceptable because we are in a dream world for almost the entire movie.  It makes sense when we stop to examine the odd way our own dreams present themselves.

While it isn't perfectly filmed and is clearly a lower budget production, Ink has a very different take on a common storyline: redemption and family.  It's well worth watching, and it's one of those movies you can come back to again in the future which makes it very shelf worthy.

(...some recommendations of what might be nice to watch instead are at the end of my review. If you're looking for a kid's movie, be sure to check the rating, not all the ones I listed are PG - Sprited Away is a fantastic choice if you are looking for something to watch with your kid and IS everything this movie and its 5-star reviews promise and fail to deliver on.) Warning - There are many sub-professional aspects to this film. If you have an academic interest in this film as a film-maker, film student, film teacher, great, but as an actual movie a consumer is thinking of purchasing or renting, think twice. If you are looking for a sort of magical journey kind of movie, your money would be much better spent going with something made by Jean-Pierre Jeunet or Guillermo Del Toro. (Hellboy 2, probably Del Toro's most mainstream movie, is STILL more artistic than Ink... and probably has far less total minutes taken up by fight scenes than Ink. Ink has a LOT of time spent on choreographed fight scenes.) Or if you haven't seen it yet, watch The Fisher King. For about the same price as renting Ink, you could get a well-written, well-shot, well-acted version of what was attempted with the Ink character. Kids and grownups would get an infinitely more wondrous journey watching Hayao Miyazaki's Spirited Away. Or heck, The Labyrinth or The Neverending Story. The film comes off as if it were a first draft. Just the way it was shot is on an amateur level - I don't mean the camera is bouncing around like Blair Witch or Cloverfield, I mean a lot of the time, the director doesn't seem to be thinking seriously about very basic things like where he is placing the actors or the camera to make the scene look interesting on a basic level. The dialogue is oftentimes badly written - the most obvious thing to say is what gets said. The plotline is predictable. Overall, it looks like someone had a bag of interesting tricks they knew they could use, some decent overall concepts, and tried to flesh that into a full length film. There was one scene in particular that was actually really interesting and it is well-enough done that anyone watching the film will recognize which scene I am referring to... but a 5 minute scene can't justify a 140+ minute movie. (... also there is a scene using almost EXACTLY the same concept in Jean-Pierre Jeunet's movie Delicatessen, not sure if that's a case of great minds think alike or heavy influence) It's obvious a lot of effort must have gone into Ink, even just from the number of locations and people involved. From that perspective... one is really tempted to start reviewing it as a student or amateur effort and cut it some slack, but this is a film being sold on amazon, not something your favorite nephew made in AV class that you will sit down and indulge for his sake. If you are looking for an evening's entertainment, you can do much, much better - in fact, you get a better chance of seeing a movie fitting this movie's description if you search elsewhere. ...how so many people could stomach this tripe.

Independent does not mean good. This film had some of the worst dialogue and plot tropes than I've ever seen -- far worse than any Hollywood blockbuster. It's as if someone gave a major budget to a film school student who'd only ever seen "The Neverending Story" and "The Grudge," who then tripped acid to a compilation of corny endings from 80's buddy cop movies interspersed with an Intro to Adobe After Effects course on loop, and created this movie on the comedown. Or perhaps the director is part of an arthouse consortium with good liberal reasons to plaster a shape wipe or a snow effect over every transition and a wash-out filter over every scene.

Seeing how many people love this movie is just like being in art school with that student and watching his crap movie get made and then cram on cute poon. This hurts the tummy almost more than watching the thing.

The acting is awful and the dialogue style stolen from Jonas Brothers slash fiction, which in tandem produce stunningly unwatchable scenes. As for the plot: it's original, but utterly confused, hookless, and melbetoast. Oozing through everything is a dense, American cheese. And what about the cinematography/special effects, you ask? They're just okay.

Bottom line: overly serious and unaware of the tropes of its genre, this movie attempts to float on the originality of its plot and crashes straight into hell. Not recommended unless you've seen less than five movies and are just trying to get your experience up.

First, I DID like this movie overall. When reading reviews and comparrisons to Dark City and Donnie Darko, I had to pick this up. Those comparrisons are way wrong. This is in no way like those movies. Meaning, it is not on thier level but is still a good obscure movie for fans of this genre.
Our story of the girl being in a coma and the plot that some beings bring us our good dreams and some bring us bad dreams was very original and I loved that part.
What made me drop my review a bit was the lack in continuity. There is a scene where a woman is in the room with the child next to her bed. She cannot be seen or touched and makes sure not to touch the girl's hair when reaching for her BUT she sits on the bed which effects the movement or interaction with the girl. Holes like this just bugged me.
One more example is when Ink is actually saving the girl but she tries to yell for help, she reaches for a woman (flat palmed) as though she was going to push her and not grab her or poke her. In real life, she would have grabbed or poked the woman. Not put her arm out like she already knew she couldn't interact with the woman.
As I said, it is a good obscure plot, well made for the most part and very original. Worth the watch but it is not on the level of the movies it is compared to.
3.5 - 4 stars (I like it) but I can't go higher on this one.

Although it has a slow start, it really comes together and is an overall great experience. Great music, sound design, and art direction.

Watch it!

I watched this movie based on the recommendation of an old friend who said that this film reminded her of me. I can see why... it had everything I could ever want in a film: story, human conflict, urban fantasy, good versus evil, heart, soul, drama, redemption, love, loss...

Basically, this film stole my heart, but it in a jar, and forgot to put air-holes in it.

I was entranced, emotionally invested, and, even though I'd figured out who Ink was by the middle, I sat through to the end with fat tears rolling down my face.

This film was clever and beautifully done for such a low budget. I'll take a good story over special effects any day.

Promptly after I'd calmed down enough I went and downloaded the soundtrack through Amazon. It is now on constant replay.

Please make more movies like this.

Love,
Kim
This movie had a number of interesting ideas in it; well worth a viewing.  Do not expect to be blown away by the plot twists or anything, but it is enjoyable and creative.

This movie sat on my shelf for quite a while before I was willing to actually watch it.  From reading the cover, and looking at the images, it really didn't appeal to me.  I find many indie movies to be pretentious and self serving, so unless I hear from someone that I need to watch one, I skip over them.

Ink was a pleasant surprise.  It's low budget was glaring within the first few minutes.  Still the production team made due with what was available.  Sets, costumes, nothing showed signs of big budgets, yet the overall aesthetics of the film were quite beautiful.  You won't find any award winning acting here, but it is done well enough to be believable and compelling.  The characters lacked depth, yet there was an empathy towards them that kept you rooting or booing for them.

The story while not uniquely unique, is different enough from the mass produced dribble that we've grown accustomed to.  On the surface, it's the time told tale of good versus evil, but underneath is a look at our inner demons, and how our choices impact those around us told in fantasy with monstrous villains, science fiction heroes, and a world just foreign enough to keep you off balance.  All through the story you're wondering is this a dream, or is it meant to be real.

I don't know if it's because of my current situation in life, or if the film was just more powerful than I expected, but it left me emotionally drained after watching it.  It touched on subjects that were close to my heart, and pulled at my emotions in ways I haven't felt in quite a while.

So if you can overlook a low budget indie title, and forgive it's minor short comings, there is a wonderful story that will tug at your heart.

I have watched this movie and my friends have watched it were not sure what the real point here is but we did enjoy it it was very dark and cryptic in its story telling. It was worth snaggin up at $10. So good luck.

I happened upon INK on Hulu where I was just looking for background noise while I did other things.  Having "half watched it" I decided to sit and give it my full attention during a second viewing. First off, I am in no way associated with the makers of this film. I am just an average guy who loved this movie. The effects are good, but not big hollywood. The story is captivating, if not completely original, but what really is now days? All in all, I highly recommend it.

All the wrong people had recommended this movie to me.  Then my fiance and I were looking around Blockbuster, and I only vaguely remembered hearing about it.  She took a shot and rented it.  As I had to work, she watched it first, and called me later to tell me how great it was.  I then left it with my brother (the most hard-boiled, cynical movie watcher ever). The second half (and especially the final moments) are some of the most beautiful and captivating scenes I've ever watched.  I don't often like movies that bring me to tears, but "Ink" never fails to deliver that "good cry" every single time I watch it.
It is just plain beautiful!

This was on Hulu one day and it had some decent reviews, so I decided to watch it, and I was more than blown away.  It wasn't a big budget movie, but the effects were amazing. As I said to all of them, I definitely recommend it!

The plot, characters, visual effects, etc were all amazingly good. And the underlying moral of the movie was extremely good too and tied in well.

This movie was recommended to me by netflix based on reviews I'd made of other movies. I'd never heard of Ink before but figured netflix has made good recommendations in the past so I checked it out. Now, having seen it, I'd say of the thousands of movies I've seen in my life this is a top 3 pick.
I wasn't sure how this would be from the camera quality and obviously low budget, but as long as you give it a chance it will blow you away. Absolutely brilliant!

Ink is a film that takes a look at the makeup of a damaged man and the doings around him.  It was good to be reminded that there is a choice, right up until the end, that we can't run from our basic nature. Worth every second of time to watch but does take an attention span to see you through.  Not enough booms and simple plot lines.

This movie starts out near its ending and then rewinds to its beginning and then goes beyond its ending and wraps around back to its ending. Sounds confusing? Maybe, but it is cleverly done so that you are kept wandering what is really happening. But isn't this what dreams are made of? It seems while you are watching this movie that your sub-conscious leaps out to contradict your own natural understanding.

What the writer of this film attempts to capture is the interface between the natural and the metaphysical/spiritual realms. The fight scenes demonstrate this marvellously well. Furniture and fixtures are broken as the warring factions of the metaphysical realm fight ... but then they reconstruct themselves to reflect their unaffected status in the natural realm.

The characters are extremely unique, the one that really stands out is the path-finder. Althought he is blind his level of perception is astounding and he is able to capture the rhythm of the universe, in order to unite father and daughter, he has to find the right element that will break the flow.

This film has some excellent special effects and reveals the nature of good and evil in the metaphysical realm. The film also deals with deep truths, such as faith and belief, and even forgiveness of one's own self.

This film is a masterpiece, whether it was a fluke or not, that remains to be determined.

Not being able to sleep one night, I wandered to the tv and browsed my netflix recommendations.  "Ink" had been long recommended to me so I picked that, expecting to fall asleep---hoping to fall asleep.  But the very opposite happened, and I sat up long into the night crying my eyes out, and standing up after it was over feeling like a better person.  This film is remarkably creative, fantastically told and executed.  It puts most big budget Hollywood blockbusters to shame.  I thought "Avatar" was the best movie I had seen (visually).  "Ink" proves that no matter how good your movie looks, it is ultimately the story that makes all the difference.

This film isn't for the faint of heart.  If you're someone who enjoys sci-fi, fantasy, alternative movies to the typical flicks---yea, you'd dig this.  But it probably would be lost on your mind if you're not a deep thinker, don't get much out of the arts, and only watch movies for entertainment value.

Seriously.  It might not have the special effect of any big Hollywood blockbuster, but it's not a story that needs it either.

This may or may not be your kind of movie.  "Snakes on a plane" wasn't really my kind of movie either, doesn't mean I'm going to discourage others from trying it out.  Everything in "ink" was superb, from the story to the directing to the acting.

So my one suggestion is watch it.  Definitely watch it for yourself, and decide if this film is for you or not.  But seriously watch it all the way through.  Everything comes together at the end, everything is explained.  So watch it entirely before shutting it off and ranting about how confusing it was so you shut it off.  Everything comes together.

"Ink" is one of the most original, well thought out stories I've ever seen in a film.  However, this is a film you can't turn your brain off for, so if you don't like a movie that stimulates your mind along with everything else, then pass it up.  Honestly after reading most of the one star reviews, I'm pretty certain that's what the issue was.  They wanted a film they didn't have to pay attention to to get or enjoy.

Yes, sometimes you want a film you don't have to think about.  A no-brainer plot that you can just mindlessly enjoy.  This isn't that.  This film is brilliant, and original and simply amazing.  But you do need to actively watch it or you'll miss its splendor.

As for those that commented only the cast and crew are the ones giving this a five star review, that's not true. I wasn't a part of this film.  Hell, check the credits and compare it to my name if you don't believe me.  I didn't work on this film.

But I do have Netflix.  I didn't know anything about this film, but noticed it and it caught my attention so I put it in my instant streaming queue.  Not knowing much about it, I ignored it for a while, in favor of the number of big studio films I hadn't had a chance to see in theaters.  After a few months I finally decided to try this one out, and coming into it not knowing a thing about this film, I would probably have been most set up to be confused by it, if this film was at all confusing.  It's not.

Just watch it.

I am not going to waste your time repeating all the four and five start reviews for Ink, but I'd like to make a a few addtional comments.

Ink has eye dazzling special effects but Ink is not just eye candy (albiet sometimes dark eye candy). The excellent story and the films ending is greater than the sum of the whole of all the eye popping effects - and this is what a sci-fi, fantasy or spiritual film should be - and which films most are not.

A few folks complained that there are some "lesser experienced" actors in Ink - but I feel this is OK in that it enhanced the naivete or innocence that was a large part of many of the characters personalities. The entire cast deserves top marks for their performances.

I also liked that Ink has a spiritual message concerning the soul, the possiblity for redemption, that someone may be looking out for us and that God exists.  Spoiler: (I believe that this is what the film was saying, because the Path-Finder (or one of the angels) speaks of God in one short scene). But - and this is important - Ink never preaches or bludgeon you with its perspectives.  In any case the final message leaves the audience with a feeling of genuine hope - a rarity with the multitude of dark nihilistc endings that we come to expect these days.

Ink displays top film-making skills in story telling, ingenuity, editing, photography, imagination, and a whole gamet of movie making techniques. The film makers also made one of the best possible uses of a very limited budget that I have ever seen. They certainly got the biggest bang for their buck!

According to Ink's director - Ink was made for $250,000 - that is truly amazing - and with the quality of the final product - easily pushes the film into 4 and 5 star category.  You will understand what I mean when you see the picture.

If you want to know more about Ink you can read all the other four and five start reviews.  Better yet - see it for yourself.

My only caveat - Ink deserves a rich 5.1 surround and not the simple two channel that is on the disks. Something to look forward too someday? Let's hope so.

It is poignant without being preachy.  It is a fairy tale on acid.  I think everyone who enjoys a movie that requires you to think about it will love Ink.

I watched Ink on a whim, a recommendation from Netflix I assumed I'd shut off in fifteen minutes. Instead, I found myself pulled into a beautiful, hypnotic world of dreams, longing and redemption: the world of "Ink".

The story follows Ink, a scarred, spectral "Drifter" who steals a young girl into a dream-like astral plane, leaving her body in a coma close to death.  He seeks to trade her for a transformation into one of the shadowy "Incubi", false-faced beings whose shadows bring horrific nightmares. Pursuing him are a group of beings called "Storytellers", whose touch brings peaceful dreaming and who seem to oppose the Incubi on general principle. Back in the real world, meanwhile, the girl's father, John, struggles to choose between his Incubus-touched ambitions and his love for his daughter and his family. Weaving amongst it all is Liev, a lone Storyteller seeking to free the girl from her captor--and Ink from his self-imposed torment.

What makes "Ink" most powerful, however, is the hypnotic beauty of its world. Soft-edged, golden dreams and the nightmarish, static-edged realm of the Incubi are woven with equal skill around the gray clarity of reality. It's a world where dreams are real and hope is possible,  even if the light of it may flicker and dim under the threat of despair and shadow. Even the action scenes are glorious, using of combat not as filler, but as a means to illustrate the running conflict between hope and despair. With little more than lighting effects and shifts in color, "Ink" deftly blurs the line between fantasy and reality, until all that matters is the intertwined struggle of Ink, his pursuers, and the obsessively driven John. When all the threads are finally pulled together and the ending is revealed, the result is nearly transcendent.

Defiant and brilliant, mystical and shadowed, "Ink" creates one of the most unique fantasy worlds I've had the pleasure of watching in quite some time. Less bleak than "Dark City", but more dreamlike than "Inception", "Ink" is highly recommended for all movie lovers--especially those with a taste for the works of Neil Gaiman or Terry Gilliam.
