Every night, people are visited by the dream-bringing Storytellers and the nightmare-producing Incubi. And caught between them is Ink.

That's the concept behind "Ink," a surreal, eerily-filmed movie clothed in haunting questions about life, death, dreams, nightmares, good and evil. Jamin Winans' second full-length movie has a pretty weird vibe -- think Neil Gaiman directing "It's a Wonderful Life" -- but it ends up being a dizzying, beautiful journey through a strange other world.

A creature named Ink appears in the bedroom of a girl named Emma, and kidnaps both her and a Storyteller named Liev. Ink  hopes to become an Incubus, and Emma is his one chance. Emma falls into a deep coma, and her father John refuses to go see her because his in-laws snatched custody of her away because of his alcohol and drug problems.

In the meantime, the Storytellers set out to rescue Emma and Liev from Ink, and must get some help from a blind Pathfinder who can change reality as he wishes. And as Ink drags his prisoners to Drifters who hold a code he must claim, Liev begins to sow seeds of doubt about what he is doing -- and his true nature and horrendous past come to light.

"Ink" is the sort of movie that people like to hold up as an example of independent cinema -- unique, groundbreaking and cool. It's filmed in that luminous grey-toned style that "Sin City" was, and Winans fills it with a sense of neo-urban surrealism -- the goth Storyteller, trash-filled warehouses, electric-tape on Jacob's eyes, and tattered pockets with weird Drifters dwelling in them.

Winans both directed and wrote this movie, and both show a lot of care. His story jumbles time, space and dimensions, playing tricks with your mind; and he crams it with slightly off-kilter scenes that  are brilliantly simple (Jacob finding "links" on an urban street). And he has a knack for horror -- the Incubi are depicted as terrifyingly, artificially cheerful screens in front of faces. You don't SEE their true faces, but you know it's horrific.

But he also shows that he can pluck at your heartstrings in rare style, particularly as we find out what Ink did to become the tattered, crowlike figure we see. The latter parts of the movie are a haunting, painful celebration of love's power, without any sappy platitudes.

Well, it would be giving away too much too much to say who/what Ink is. So I'll just say that Christopher Soren Kelly is brilliant at conveying Ink's tortured emotions from inside a shell of rags and a beak-nose. Jessica Duffy comes across as artificial when talking to Emma, but does a decent job otherwise; Jennifer Batter is simply brilliant as a warm-hearted goth Storyteller who is determined to save Emma. And Jeremy Make is just FREAKING BRILLIANT as the delightfully eccentric, infuriating Jacob.

"Ink" is a near-seamless blend of horror, action and fantasy -- and while Jamin Winans does brilliant things with film, he's also an excellent storyteller. Just not the butt-kicking kind.

Ink is a great movie! Its complex enough to still be interesting after watching it over and over again, and yet simple enough that you can get the story line in the first sitting. The actors all do a great job and the Path Finder is the funniest character I have come across in a long time.

Wow.  This film is so far beyond its paygrade, so different from anything I've ever seen I am struggling with words to describe it.  Like another reviewer I almost ejected the DVD a few minutes in.  Fortunately I caught a glimpse of something familiar in a mundane street scene and realized it was filmed on location in Denver (my old hometown stomping grounds) so I gave it a chance.  My reward?  A new all time movie favorite.

Basically this is a fantasy film about redemption revolving around dreamscapes, life's choices, love, shame and reclamation.  The initial scene is startling... the back-story line unfolds with an ordinary suburban street as backdrop, slides into dream and continues as a parallel tale unfolds in the main characters' real lives and dreamlife (or is it the after-life?  Hmm).  It's so quirky, the timing is flawless and the plot so full of twists it will keep you guessing.  Sorry folks I want you to be as clueless about its content as I was when I watched it.  You will get no help from me!  Just watch and be amazed.  Two thumbs way up especially for the filmmakers' vision (and their attention to detail in their presentation of) the storytellers, pathfinder, and incubus characters.

As each scene unfolded I found myself wondering "who ARE these geniuses?  Is this really an indy film?"  By the closing credits I was touched to the core.  And after learning more about the creators and production in the bonus material I was absolutely slack-jawed with awe.  Everything about this film is unique.  Everything from the concept to the screenplay to the costuming, casting, lighting and music was of the highest quality.  My respect for the Winans knows no bounds.  In a way I feel sorry for them - how can they possibly outdo this one?  The quality they achieved on a $250,000 budget exceeds 90% of the garbage coming out of Hollyweird.  Watch -- no, BUY this film and tell your friends!

I watched this movie on a whim a few nights ago. I found it confusing at first and almost turned it off to watch something else. I'm glad I hung in there for a few more scenes. Ink is by far one of the best scifi/fantasy films I have seen in a long time.

I watched it again tonight, this time with my husband. I gave him a bit of an overview before he watched it just so he wouldn't be as confused as I was at the beginning. He enjoyed it as much as I did.

I was glad to find a movie that is a little more cerebral than the standard scifi/fantasy fare that is offered these days. I liked the themes of guilt/shame/pride and ultimately redemption. Bravo for Indie films! You won't find this kind of intelligence from standard Hollywood movies.

I heard about Ink via Netflix, and after watching it (the Blu-Ray edition), I must say - I was very impressed.

The story is about a battle over the life of a little girl - in dream-land and in real-life.  Will she be taken, or will she live?  A universe filled with dream-land warriors seeks to battle for her fate in the real world.  Storytellers, Pathfinders, and Incubi.  Hospital visits and business deals.

The film is rather rough around the edges - the acting isn't top notch with no-names, it feels like it was shot on home video cameras.  It reminded me of lower-budget professional films:  Fireproof, the Left Behind series, stuff you'd see on SyFy on a Sunday afternoon, etc.  It's indie - take it for what you will.

However, I was able to ignore the above for one simple reason:  the material was better.  The SFX are great, the visuals are haunting, the story is moving.  It does have an amateur feel - but I actually didn't find this a distraction.  In a sense, it made the film more real... how many people do you really know who act or behave in the fashion popular actors do in Hollywood films?  The people in this film said things that I could see my friends saying, acted the way my friends would act.

I am 48 years old and have seen just about everything out there.  Ink has become my all-time-favorite movie and there's nothing that comes close.  I'm not a movie critic so I'll keep this short.  The plot was outstanding.  The actors and acting was superb.  The musical score was out of this world.  Well done!  I am quite picky about things but cannot find anything to complain about.  I purchased the blu-ray from Amazon and downloaded the soundtrack from Amazon as fast as I could after seeing the movie on Netflix.  It's amazing what talent can do that millions of dollars in manpower and affects cannot!

I was pleasantly suprised by this film, so much so, in fact, that I felt compelled to write my first Amazon review in what's probably been years(and no...I'm not in any way related to the film makers). Since others have already discussed the plot, I won't rehash it here. I'll just talk about what I liked and my experience watching the film.

Knowing that it was an indie film with a tiny budget, I wasn't expecting much. But it got good reviews, so I thought I'd give it a whirl. When the movie began, it was about as I expected. Some wooden acting and a bit of a hum-ho, predictable script (thus, 4 stars rather than 5). However, once things got rolling, this movie really pulled me in, and I even shed a tear or two towards the end. While not perfect, I think as a whole the film was very entertaining, and even thought provoking in parts.

I was really impressed by the visual aspects of the film, and even more so when I watched the short "making of" in the special features. I couldn't believe how creative they were with using everyday materials. I also thought that the lack of super-high-end computer effects (which are so predictably present in just about every movie these days) was actually a good thing. The directors had to focus on the story and enhance the story with visuals, rather than cover up the lack of a story with fancy CGI.

I also enjoyed the fact that the directors didn't shove the background mythology in your face (like where the storytellers and incubi come from, why they do what they do, where live live, etc etc). They gave you enough to make it interesting, but withheld enough to let you formulate your own ideas and ponder the film after watching it.

If you like sci-fi/fantasy or fairytells, I would recomend this film. Don't go into it expecting "the best film ever." But if you keep an open mind and can get past a little wooden acting and focus on the story, you should be as pleasantly suprised as I was.

I watched it glued to the screen. Its a great movie. Its not predictable at all and the actors a really good for unknowns (or fairly unknowns). They even have some "steam punk" usage, actually quite a bit, and the special effects are reasonable and not the main point of the movie. It actually has a story line and a plot, something missing in most of the new releases we are getting out of hollywood these days that are weak in that department. I would recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys fantasy/sci-fi/drama type movies. It is a bit of a tear jerker in the end, so let me warn you, it does grab your heart, holds it, and then squeezes for sympathy and compassion.

Disturbing and thought provoking. Proof yet again that big money production is nothing compared to thoughtful and skilled production. Parts were filmed in Denver with a CU Boulder connection. NOT for CHILDREN. I really enjoyed it.

I absolutely loved this gem of a film and had no idea what the heck it was when I rented it from Blockbuster. I don't pirate movies, so I didn't hear of it that way, I just picked it up on a whim because I liked the synopsis and was curious to see why it was compared to other great surreal flicks such as Dark City, Pan's Labyrinth, Matrix and Donnie Darko. Well, it really isn't anything like those other films other than having a parallel dream world as part of the plot and it is exceptional in its own right. I am shocked it was made for only $250,000, what efficient filmmaking! There are skin flicks on Cinemax which cost that much to make. The style and artistic direction really made this film look higher budget than it is and the exceptional acting by Chris Kelly and Quinn Hunchar gave life to the main characters.  The car accident was very well done. I also love tales of redemption.

Not every movie is for everyone, but this one really tugged at my heart while spoiling my eyes with visual flare.  What the movie lacks in special effects and CGI they make up for with a stylistic saturation of colors, similar to what you would see in a music video.  This helps the film focus on what matters the most, story and pacing.  I will be adding this to my collection while keeping an eye on talented writer/director, Jamin Winans.

This is an amazing movie made by people who love cinema and that gave all their effort to make thier dream came true. Without fanancial help they did something really incredible. Like "Donnie Darko" this film has a lot of different interpretations. Warning, if you are a Hollywood garbage lover maybe you are not going to like it. If you want to watch something new and enjoy a great script with the hard work of good "unknown" actors, INK is for you. One more time this people demonstrate that it is possible to make excellent films without great budgets. You only need imagination and hard work. Congratulations!!!!

This movie got good reviews from consumers on Amazon.  I was not so impressed.  Maybe I will have to watch it several times.  But some of the acting was bad.  It took a while to figure out who the characters really were.

"Ink" shows why we need indie movies, and just how high a standard they can reach. This movie defies easy description: there's a family drama centered on a ruthless workaholic, but layered together with a fantastical faceoff between unexplained agents of positive and negative dreamworlds. And, despite a total lack of explanation for anything, the two clearly tell the same story. Visuals (no I won't give any spoilers) have impact despite simplicity - I don't know the name for the dark force in this flick, but they make The Strangers from Dark City look positively jovial. Effects are simple but effective, like the windows and furniture that shatter and reform as the otherworld combatants throw each other around. Even things like color and contrast demarcate different dimensions of this complex world, helping to orient a visitor like me to what's where and when. Editing has a jagged, nervous quality that some might find jarring - it seemed to me just to echo the uncertain qualities of every reality involved. On top of it all, they got a child actor, a very cute girl who looks to be eight or so, with more range and presence than a few headliners I can name. No big studio would have put a buck behind this complex, intelligent, and dark fantasy. No one snappy catchphrase sums it all up, no one comparison orients anyone trying to imagine it. And it certainly isn't for viewers who need full explanations and clear direction - you're picked up and thrown into a story with huge unspoken history and rules only guessed as you go along. But, if you follow the most brilliant innovations in cinematic story-telling, this has to be on your list. - wiredweird

'Avatar' cost a $-half-billion-$ to make - 'Ink' around $250K

But 'Ink' is a superior film.

I'm not sure how to break down the economics of this
but I'll offer my best shot at explaining
how something like this might have happened.

'Ink' had a better story, characters, plot, atmosphere and more heart & soul.

That's my best analysis.

One of the most spellbinding movies I've ever seen. It so beautifully portrays the multiple-layered nature of reality. As an independent film it's a little rough around the edges. But the atmosphere, themes, and innovative visual style more than make up for it.

I found INK on Netflix and was so intrigued by the story and thought provolking visuals, I had to own it. If you like to dream and often wonder about the power of good and evil...this DVD paints an interesting view.

Particularly interesting about this DVD was the special feature showing all the effort that went into making "Ink". The director made a great effort to make this film within his budget and wound up producing a very visually stunning film filled with interesting characters and scenery.

The main story is a fantasy about a young girl and her father interacting with creatures that inhabit a dream-like world. One set of beings are responsible for dreams while others generate nightmares. The story takes off when the girl's "soul" is snatched up by the character named "Ink", for some nefarious purpose. This action causes a related series of events revolving around the estranged father and the girl, the battle between the dream and nightmare people and the father's sense of guilt, regret, loss and redemption.

Despite the small budget, Ink is a remarkable film that is visually appealing with a great ending. I especially liked the way the "cause and effect" theme was explored in this film. Its good to see that this was not another quickie horror/sex comedy/slasher flick - which is usually the kind of small budget film that I see stocked at the local video store. Ink is worth finding and watching.

After seeing all the rave reviews for this movie, I'm utterly shocked as to how so many people could praise such a film. I love almost every indie movie I see. But this movie gets two thumbs down. Bad story, horrible acting, awful directing, and bad editing all make for a terrible production. Looks like a film a teenager could make with a $10 budget or less. Also, the washed out filter effect is annoying to watch. Don't bother with this one.

I came across 'Ink' by chance and watched it by myself one evening. Everything about the film touched me so deeply: the complex and interesting storyline (a beautifully executed morality tale with various other elements and themes); The acting; The visuals; the music. I firmly believe that Jamin Winans, the film's writer/director/composer, will make a lasting name for himself if he continues to come up with projects this original and stunning. The music literally brought me to tears as I watched the film. In fact, I was so moved by the film, I viewed it a second time immediately after the first, which is something I can honestly say I've NEVER done before with any other movie. I cannot stop telling my friends about this film. My suggestion? Rent or buy 'Ink' -- you won't be disappointed.

It's been a long, long time since a movie ended, and all I could say was "wow". Ink has more true creativity, more real entertainment, and more emotional depth than an entire year's worth of Hollywood films. If Ink doesn't win an Academy Award, it will reveal for once and for all those awards' complete irrelevance. The fact that it was shot on a shoestring with no commercial studio backing was just plain heroic.  Strangely enough, even though Ink is a dark fable, there were more real laughs in it than in any three major Hollywood comedies. I can't say enough about this visually stunning movie: it's one of the most memorable DVD experiences I've ever had.
I rate this as the "worst movie of 2009."  Poor story, bad editing, low-quality video, annoying non-special effects, mediocre and forgettable acting, story line that makes no sense, etc, etc.

I read some of the great reviews and then for the hell of it read the one and two star reviews. For the record (and it's obvious from my 5-star rating) I loved this movie. So why do some people hate it? Why would anyone hate it?

Well, maybe I can save you the trouble of wasting your money. If you're the type of person who's looking for a horror flick or another Matrix movie, skip this one. It's not for you. It's not Raiders or Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings. OK? It's an Indie picture made on a limited budget and it absolutely Rocks! with innovative and artful cinematic elements. Have I figured it out completely? No, I admit, not completely. But that's part of its beauty. It's cryptic and it plays with you through time and space. It's not a sci-fi, and it's not a pure fantasy. Thematically it's a movie about the battles we fight within ourselves every day. If you like fantasy stories full of allegory, and if you also don't need to have your movies wrapped up in little balls all neat and tidy, you'll probably like it. Conversely, if you have a problem watching movies about alternate realities, angels and demons, heaven and hell, yin yang, existentialism, etc., save your money and go rent Rocky IV.

This movie is a delightful little indie flick. It's a gripping story that packs an emotional punch and goes far beyond expectations. Also the back story of this independent film's success is pretty awesome in its own right.

When I popped in the DVD I thought it might be an interesting little supernatural sci-fi type fare that would be pretty standard but entertaining. But it definitely blew me out of the water in terms of the depth of the story and the characters. The father in particular is compelling and it's tragic to see him struggle with the events of his life.

I highly recommend checking out this flick. After it's release it became one of the most torrented films which is largely the reason it has experienced the success it has. The filmmakers have embraced this fact, and I think it is an awesome example of how powerful the internet can be for distribution. Personally I went out and purchased the DVD after seeing it, because I thought it was worth supporting.

Just watched this movie a few hours ago and felt compelled to submit my 5 star rating. Its been a while since a movie moved me the way this film did. What amazes me most is that I've never even heard of this film until I stumbled upon it while browsing an instant movie to watch on Netflix. I was simply awe struck by this film. Everything about it, the story, the cinematography, the music, etc.. was amazing. The acting and fighting scenes were great and although freaky the Incubus characters were quite interesting to watch.  Very well done on all aspects of acting and special effects especially given the small budget this film had to work with. Do yourself a favor and watch this film. Its one of those movies that will stick with you.

Confusing at first, if you stick with it, you will be rewarded.  Greatly rewarded.  It is a brilliantly clever and inventive fantasy/sci fi story of a dangerous journey to redemption.  You will get involved with the characters.  You will care.  And the settings?  I was shocked to find out this movie was done on a $250k budget.  It has probably been downloaded 1,000,000 times or more and the producer didn't make a dime.  If we want incredible and different movies like this, we need to support the makers.  Buy it, you'll love it.

It's hard to describe how much I enjoyed this film.  Especially without sounding trite.  But "Ink" is undeniably exquisite.  The story it tells, the themes it brings in, the visuals, the soundtrack... everything is so poignant and just... beautiful.  "Ink" may be dark, it may have some harshness in it that is not entirely appropriate for children, but anyone who can stand some language and reality should watch it.

This film is simply awe-inspiring.  Well done, Jamin Winans and crew.  Very well done indeed.

This film is an astoundingly good piece of work.  It is what films such as "The Prophecy" and "Constantine" should have been instead of what they were.  It is heavily influenced (in the best possible way as far as I'm concerned) by visual styles from films like "12 Monkeys" and "City of Lost Children."  While I wouldn't say this film is perfect, it does have enough moments of perfection in it -- i.e.: cinema exists so that sequences like the one starting near minute 58 can be shown -- that I'd be afraid of people trying to improve it.  As near as I can tell, the MPAA would rate it R almost exclusively for language; there is mild (brawling) violence and no sex.
Amazing film, I went in having no expectations and was blown away.  Deeply moving and the cinematics were brilliant.

If you're a hard working businessman or businesswoman in any discipline, and you like movies with intense suspense / wondering what will happen next, this is a really really great movie -- the kind that is unforgettable.  I first saw it some 8+ years ago and still love it.  It's unforgettable -- the kind of movie which will pop into your memory as you proceed through your life for years to come.  It's out-of-the-box and very unusual -- nothing is predictable or routine about it.  The write-ups make it sound like a horror movie, and/or a sci-fi, and/or science-fantasy but it's different than any of those categories for  sure.  You just have to see it.  The movie does start off slow and strange/foreign/bizarre/uncomprehensible but within 15 minutes or so, like the great Matrix, the pieces start falling into place.  This movie is a must-see especially for young men on the fast tract in corporate life but so too for everyone else.  It's that rare kind of movie you'll insist all your adult friends see so you can discuss it with them.  BUY IT before it is sold  out.  And when they gonna make part 2?!?!?
At first I found the movie confusing but by the end I love the message in it.

I accidentally rented this movie but it turned out to be a great accident.  You MUST watch more then the first 15 minutes though!!!!  The movie starts off kinda strange and you might be tempted to turn it off, DONT.  Things get explained and really start to make sense.  Now I do like sci fi and fatasy movies so I am slightly biased towards this movie but I really liked it.  Its obvious its not a big budget movie BUT its not total cheese either.  Some of the scenes and the music are really good.  I highly recommend this movie and think the people who gave it 1 star are jaded by watching to many big budgeted special effect movies to really appreiciate a well made indepent film.  Their loss.  Enjoy!

I figured out the plot of this film very early, but still enjoyed it. It is a morality tale, but with the amount of Narcissism in the world, I'm for anything that asks people to look at themselves. It is basically a story of a father's relationship to his daughter. The plot is complicated by people from other dimensions who control the dreams humans have and inspire them to good or evil. It is the old God versus the Devil scenario, but with a more psychological focus and hot new age warriors who battle strange entities.

The "evil" entities who represent the sin of "pride" are black clad figures whose faces are projected eerily onto glass plates suspended in front of their real faces. "Ink" is a dark side "wanna be" character who is trying to earn his place with the group by delivering a child to them. To me one of the biggest flaws in this film is the rather laughable fake nose and obvious rubber mask worn by Ink. It made a very scary figure look like a homeless, former reveler in a poorly done Italian Carnival mask.

The simple plot is augmented by a few "new age" ideas, such as those of the blind character "Pathfinder" who can orchestrate links between seemingly unrelated things in order to create major events. The special effects work but are not worth your Blu-ray dollar because of how they are done. They consist of grainy film clips, film tinting, overexposure and creative editing work. None of these look better when augmented with a sharper image.

I am glad I bought this film sight unseen, having only heard some good things in the alt. press.  'Ink' is not a major film, it didn't have a major release, or advertising.  It was made by a couple in Colorado who wanted to make it.  They raised the money to do the project themselves.  Their friends helped. They made their own costumes, made their own music.  The actors are mostly unknown, and up and coming.

I don't want to give away the plot hook, suffice it to say that Ink is a modern fairytale about fatherhood, told as a battle between forces of light and darkness, with the key players being a girl in a coma, and her estranged father. The supporting characters are the Storytellers, beatific beings who give people good dreams, and the Incubus, dark beings who give people nightmares. And then there is the enigmatic Ink, who carries Emma into the dreamrealm, to sacrifice her to the Incubus to insure his transformation into one of them.  The how and the why is where the real drama of this film lies, and it's ultimate revelation is one the most emotionally profound moments of redemption in any film I saw of 2009. It brought me to tears. Finding it in such a small film is quite special.

I did find there was a confusing bit of character development in the film that felt like a cheat, but on repeat viewings realized the film uses a non-linear narrative device. The title of this review is the clue.

A word on the transfer: this film is quite beautiful in hi-def.  Now, there are alot of overblown contrasts, image softening and color treatments, some heavy digital noise in the darkest segments, but detail is usually very sharp, if not striking.  I found all of the photography choices quite clever, and lend to a strong nostalgic feel. The sound mix is very clear at low volume, except for the dialogue gets a little quiet near the climax.  The music by director Jamin Winans is magisterial, and perfectly lends to the action and emotion of the story.

I can't recommend this film enough. Rent it. Buy it.

The story of Ink centers around a man who's life is in a downward spiral. He's grief-stricken over his wife's death, he's estranged from his daughter, and a major deal for his business is at risk of falling through. The story is also about two factions of warring spirits. The Storytellers, in balance with their emotions, bring pleasant dreams to humanity, guiding people towards their potential. The Incubi, on the other hand, have cut themselves off from their emotions, hiding behind a facade of vanity and pride, living in a hell of their own creation. They bring nightmares to humanity, drawing the vulnerable in to share their fate.

The movie is an excellent piece of independent cinema. The fantastic elements are interesting and fit well with the visual style of the movie, the story starts off enigmatic but fits together in the end, the visual effects do a wonderful job of conveying the blending of dream and reality, and the cinematography is stunning. The movie was done on a shoestring budget and the studio is doing their own distribution.

If you like independent cinema and dark modern fantasy, buy a copy.

This was recommended to me based on other films I'd seen.  I had heard absolutely nothing about it coming in.  At first I was a bit put off by the low budget camera work and obvious raw acting by some of the cast.  I thought it was going to be another cheesy direct-to-DVD snooze fest.  However, as the film went on it grew on me.  At the end I was hooked.  Ink left me with the same feeling that other visually-striking films such as The Fall, Dark City, and Equilibrium did.  I wanted to watch it again, and it stuck with me days after I'd seen it.

After researching the film and the writer/director/producer/composer/etc. Jamin Winans, I was thoroughly impressed with what he had created.  This is an extremely talented man who made a very impressive film about the internal struggles many of us experience every day.

Did everything work in this film?  Not at all.  But the overall story was thought-provoking and lasting.  Not every performance was nailed but the leads were very impressive.  I especially thought Chris Kelly did an outstanding job of showing a range of emotions and really captured the essence of a man at the end of his rope.

All in all, I think Winans got everything he possibly could have with the resources around him.  I have a feeling this is just the beginning of a solid career for him.  Support independent film and check this one out.  It may not be a global masterpiece, but it beats most of the big-budget films I've seen in a while.

Since everyone else appears to either love or hate this movie, I will give an indifferent opinion.

Loads of spoilers now follow ...

Intriguing at times, but sorry ending. Too many loose ties, but I loved music score, the cheap effects (were well done), the fact that it mostly tried to be original and the little girl Emma was cute.

What was the purpose of the storyteller .. I missed something there? That Ink was the girls father .. good, but the connection between the father being with the girl in a coma and the girl in the 'dream' and both having to save her at the same time, even though time operates differently .. very tenuous. Why was the girl so important to everyone? How come all the fantasy figures had superhuman fighting powers? And so on.

In summary, worth the time to watch, but not well thought out script.

3 and 1/2 stars.

I rented INK because a good friend of mine recommended it to me. I went into it without any preconceived notions since I'd never even heard of the film before, much less read any reviews. Let me just say that those giving this film 1-2 stars are way off their mark. Say what you want about cinematography and production values (this is a low budget film) the movie is convincingly beautiful and at times spectacular. There are moments where it has rough edges (for example the 2nd "drifter" is very much overdone) but cumulatively this is a very enjoyable film. The story is a bit hard to follow at times and occasionally the acting runs a little thin, but that is overcome by believable central characters and a few very interesting and well done scenes. I absolutely loved the 'butterfly effect' montage in the middle of the film, as well as the film's concluding sequence. The central love story was very well done and convincing--a love story that actually showed some characterization instead of just sexuality as shorthand for love.

The best part of the film? The score. Flat out the best score I've heard in quite a long time. Ambient, downbeat, symphonic; it elevates the film a whole star in my opinion and takes what would simply be a 'good' movie and makes it into a memorable one. There is so much tripe pushed out by Hollywood these days that it's nice to see a lower budget film put them in their place. This is a wonderful little film, and if you enjoy science fiction or fantasy, you'd be remiss to skip it.

4/5 Stars.

I had no idea what a huge impact this film would make on me.  When a movie manages to scare you, wow you, excite you and bring you to tears then there's definitely great story telling happening.  Please check out "Trailer #1" online, you should know where to look.  Words sometimes can't do it justice.  I still get chills even watching the trailer.  I'd classify this movie as a fantasy/drama/sci-fi but as you may have read already, there really is nothing like this movie, and that's another strong point.  So many movies these days are so big-budget and CGI-based that all you are left with is hollow, flash in the pan entertainment.  Certainly the low budget for this independent film is obvious, but with a clever use of some simple effects, lighting and unique costumes & sets - you are still blown away due to the creativity and powerful story.

I also have never noticed such an incredible use of sound effects in a movie before.  Most note worthy is the metal cigarette lighter flick sound when the beings appear in our world.  Amazing choice.  I don't just hit 5 stars because I like a movie.  Ink deserves every one.  Please do not miss out on such an amazing piece of work, a true art form in itself rooted deep with emotions we can relate to.

I found this movie on Netflix on Demand and had never heard of it and had no idea what it was about other than the short synopsis of the movie provided to me. This movie is a low budget movie but I found the story so moving and beautiful. I think a lot of people will miss out on this movie due to not being able to focus on the story and be absorbed into it but for those who are able they will leave knowing they have just seen something very special. This movie will be one of my personal favorites.

Shot high contrast in a hazy, diffusion filter (probably post-production effects) this film effectively evokes the dream state, which is its subject matter. Not as brilliant as a David Lynch dream sequence, yet not caricaturized. It has a "Dark City" feel to it but less existential and, for lack of a better word, more dreamy.

The plot fails to capture until maybe half way through, but ultimately satisfies despite some cliches and awkwardly misplaced dialogue.

For my taste - and the reason I bestow 4 and not 3 stars -  the cinematography saves the film. The birch forest shots are truly breathtaking. Also memorable is the sequence orchestrating the protagonist's car crash. Good stuff there.

The soundtrack compliments the subject matter and style nicely and offers a few memorable high points. It's something I might buy if available.

Overall a 3 star movie for most people I suppose. I bumped to 4 based on my own bias for beautiful shots and pleasing soundtrack.

Originality is what perpetuates this movie and illustrates independent movie making at its best. Its the best film I've seen in a very long time. + plus I am a proud purchaser of this movie --especially in blu-ray. I can't wait to see what the future holds for this upcoming director/writer.

Stumbled across this gem on Netflix and just happened to watch it one day.  It was fabulous.  It's imaginative, mesmerizing, and mend-bending.  A truly great science fiction/fantasy film.  Packed with well-choreographed action scenes, but also deeply moving and intelligent.  Reminds of me of the Matrix a bit, only more emotionally deep.  The story involves a battle between unseen forces of good and evil that seem to battle for individual souls while people sleep and dream.  This cosmic battle is juxtaposed against the battle one workaholic and alcoholic man wages in his own soul.  Highly recommended.

I stumbled accross this film online without any prior knowledge of this film. As I watched, it became obvious that it must be a low budget Indie film. BUT, I am another reviewer that has to say it's probably the best new release I've watched in the last five years.

I have to say right off that I believe it's going to be something you either love or hate. In no way would this fit into the generic class of movies dribbling out of hollywood to attract all classes of viewers. Reading through the reviews, both positive and negative, I notice that several of the 1 or 2 star reviews still have positive remarks about this film, but like I say, you will either love it or hate it and it just didn't click with them.

If you have a desire for unique, thought provoking, films that drive your inner voice to cheer or feel for the characters, then I highly recommend you give this one a try. Few movies today accomplish the emotional response that this one did for me. Most big budget films are all eye candy visual stimulation lacking any emotional attachment to the characters nor do they have thought provoking storylines.

Pros:
Minimal dialoge: I for one appreciate a visual story without endless dribble from the actors that make standard movies understandable without even having to WATCH the movie and this film accomplishes it completely. You must pay attention to this one and appreciate the nuances of the visuals to create your own understanding as it progresses. All of it comes together at the finale.

Special effects: I felt the special effects to be top notch for such a low budget film. As I watched I assumed it was probably made in the 10s or 20s of millions, not the 250,000 I discovered after the fact. Incredible !!!

Acting: With minimal dialoge, the acting becomes a visual function. The look on the brunette's face during the chain reaction seen is exactly as mine must have been as I watched in amazement. I found that all of the main characters were very convincing with there facial cues. The little girl "Emma" seemed as if she were a pro.

Music: Perfect fit. Nothing that would live on forever, but high quality.

Cinamatography: Angles, lighting, scenes - top notch. As good or better than big budget movies.

Cons:

The nose,,, mission accomlished. I think it had to be intentional, as I now I realize how much it drew my attention to the Ink character.

Simplistic sets: Typical urban streets, nothing flashy. Although I do not necessarily view this as something that was a drawback. Only that it was the first thing that tipped me off that it must have been a low budget film.

I saw this movie at StarFest in Denver. It is one of the best genre movies I've seen. Completely original and thought-provoking. Add this to your collection of movies that you'll love to watch over and over.

I had the good fortune to first see "Ink' at the Starz Film Center as a featured film right after it's triumphant festival debut in California...and returned 3 more times to fully absorb this finely crafted and brilliantly-conceived film. I have recommended it to everyone I know, especially film connoisseurs. I own the BluRay, and the transfer is excellent. Highly recommended for anyone who appreciates a well-made, thought provoking, visually stunning and very personal film.

If you are a dreamer, a wisher, a liar, a hoper, a prayer, a magic-bean-buyer. If you're a pretender, come sit by my fire, for we have some flax-golden tales to spin. Come in! Come in!

This movie is not for everyone.  If you like mainstream cinema you probably won't like this.  On the other hand if you abhor mainstream cinema, if you cringe at one-liners and overplayed, under-dressed actresses, if you watch movies because of their directors and their writers instead of their actors then perhaps you will like this.  There is no way to describe what it is about because it loses too much in the telling.  Simply put, this film was one of the most interesting, most creative, most poignant pieces that I have witnessed in the last 10 years.  Waking Life, the Matrix, Being John Malkovich... the film ranks among these cult beauties.  And yet it's like nothing you have ever seen.  If you are moved by the strangeness inside and outside of man's heart then come in and sit by the fire.

This is only the second review of anything I have ever experienced or purchased.  Working nights, I need my sleep, but this film made me forgo some.  I started reading some reviews from others, but felt it would taint my opinion.  Browsing the video store shelves, this caught my eye only after my third circuit around (needed to use my coupon before it expired).  The plot appealed (good/evil), darkness, innocents... The jacket with the recommendations (by who?) gave me pause, but what the hey.
  The prologue, a bit dry, but it sets the scene. Then, wow, instantly arresting.  The understated soundtrack was hauntingly appropriate; the sometimes monochromatic look, intermixed with amazing landscape shots, kept me mesmerized.  I get extremely nauseated by hand-held camera footage but I didn't realize until post-reflection how much there was (or little...I'm not sure--there's better stuff to comment on).  Yes, the dialogue felt a little stilted and the father comes across stereotypical, but I went with it.  And was rewarded.  Immensely.
  The editing is superb and is a large part of what makes this film FEEL the way it feels.  You know I like the soundtrack.  The camera does justice to all it frames, sometimes achingly so (especially...mmmm...Jessica Duffy).  The characters are "in your face" easy to hate or like (obviously not a film that makes you continually question your values as you watch).  Sit back, or lean forward, and let the film tell its story.  And later, as it did to me, it flits in the edges of your memory, finally compelling one to KNOW, to learn more, to wish it didn't end, and finally to share. Enjoy.

I started to watch this film, then turned it off, disappointed at the poor video-like quality, stilted dialoge and acting.  Then, with nothing else to watch I resumed.  I became interested, then enthralled.
The director said that he used a lot of 'cheap tricks' for the effects, and that much of the impact of the scenes comes from post-production work.  For instance, some of the costumes wouldn't even pass for bad Halloween costumes.  Yet the final product is often very effective.  That was part of the enjoyment for me, being able to see the limited means put to such creative use.
The movie makes and works within its own fantasy world of multiple levels of reality and kinds of beings, much of which is symbolic of ideas from Christain theology and mythology: good and evil beings fighting over humans, Divine Providence, redemption through suffering and humility...

All the 4-5 star reviews, just like on Netflix, are by the people involved directly with the movie and friends/family.  In general, the movie is on par with a made-for-TV SYFY Channel produced movie, and we know how good those movies are... [insert sarcasm].

Yes, it's an indie movie with a limited budget.  I could care what the budget of the movie is -- all I want to see is a good movie and if it costs $15k, $15MM, or $150MM to do it then whatever, it's a means to the end.  That being said, this movie feels very amateur.  The plot, dialogue, and acting are weak with somewhat annoying characters.  The good: the special effects and lighting are good (for the budget) in many areas (ex. the bad dream guys); the fight sequences are fairly good as well, but a little too much "shaky-cam" and choppy/chaotic editing.

All in all, while not trying to be mean to the filmmaker, I would rather have those 2 hours of my life back as the movie wasn't very good, and not even close to what some of the "reviews" were saying.  The way they're giving these false reviews is going to have a backlash effect with people, like myself, feeling ripped-off and leaving honest reviews about the movie's short-comings.

I bought Ink on one single recommendation from a stranger on a forum here on Amazon. I've never been so pleasantly surprised by a blind movie purchase in my life!
Ink is an independent film, not with an enormous budget, but it doesn't stop it from being an incredible film with gorgeous visuals. You can see how much work went into every single second of this film. This movie stands out among everything else I've seen in a long time. Absolutely unique. The acting was fantastic, especially the acting from the young girl Quinn Hunchar, playing the character Emma. The ideas were original, the characters interesting, and the plot was engaging. And the ending... prepare for one hell of an ending. And some of you will need to keep some tissues close... A description on the back of the package compares the movie to Brazil, Donnie Darko, The Matrix, Dark City, and Pan's Labyrinth. I would definitely group it in with those films, although it is not a ripoff of any of those films at all.
Quick synopsis: there is another world, a dream world where two sides are fighting to control our dreams. Some our bringing us pleasant dreams, and others, the incubi, are bringing us nightmares. A battle ensues over the soul of a little girl named Emma, trapped in their world while in a coma... and the deciding factor falls on two men: John in the waking world, Emma's father, and Ink, a rogue warrior in the dream world, fighting to rid himself of his scars and shame.
This movie is absolutely incredible, please do yourself a favor and check it out.

...but really, this wasn't much of a movie.  Silly, unlikeable comic-book characters (no, not "graphic novel," but more like a hasty '80s knock-off of some dimly-remembered '50s meme); rote chopsocky "fights" that go on and on with lots of grunts and people being hurled around and smashed against things without suffering any damage; endless "we need another 30 seconds of filler" passages of captive girls being led or dragged on meaningless treks.  When it was over, I thought well, maybe reading too many good adventure/horror/graphic novels has made me jaded and it really wasn't that bad, so I turned to my friend Ruth who had also sat through it and said "So, what did you think?"  She hemmed and hawed a bit so I said "Well, how would you rate it?"  She asked "On what scale?" and I replied "One to five, where five is something you just can't wait to watch again, and one is something you can only barely refrain from killing me because I suggested it."  "That helps," she said.  "Minus three."  And I have to go with that.  If you're twelve years old or under, you may enjoy it.  If you're an adult with reasonable expectations from a movie, chances are your experience will be somewhat different.  (Note that the glowing blurbs, er, 'reviews' quoted on the box are from "Ain't It Cool News" and "Film School Rejects", and that the line "INK has been compared to cult classics BRAZIL, DONNY DARKO, THE MATRIX, DARK CITY and PAN'S LABYRINTH" doesn't quote sources, nor does it even venture so far as to say whether or not the comparisons were favorable or derogatory.)

I don't often post reviews unless I was absolutely astounded or absolutely repulsed, in the case of Ink I was not repulsed. One of the most interesting and moving movies I have seen in a long time. I hate using the term brilliant because it's vastly overused however I think this one case where it's hard to describe it in any other way. The acting is decent for such a low budget movie, the story is incredibly original, the cinematography is excellent and the visual effects rival anything that a big budget Hollywood movie can provide. It's a movie that makes you think and keeps you guessing until the end. it's a movie with action, adventure, dark fantasy, horror, drama and sci-fi all rolled into one amazing cinematic experience. If you're tired of bland movies with no originality and want to watch something intelligent and unusual then don't miss seeing this! I'd give it six stars if I could!

Run away from this supposedly movie! Bad acting, Poor action, Poor scenario, Poor story! Unless you are a christian or in the comunity, just forget! Same kind of......let me say, Facing the giants (ugh!!) Fireproof! (double ugh!!).
Make yourself a favor and save your money!!RUN!!!!

I stumbled across this movie on Netflix Instant Watch and loved it from scene one.  The concept is original and resonant.  The effects are ingenious.  The plot and theme are compelling and profound.  I bought a copy, because this is a movie I'll want to watch again.

this movie has poor acting and obvious dialog. that being said, i love this film. the world that it creates and the story it tells are captivating and emotionally moving. this is a great fantasy film. if you are a fan of Neil Gaiman's "Mirrormask" or "Neil Gaiman's Neverwhere" this film is highly recommended.

First off I need to say that all the people that criticize this film's "poor quality" do not understand that this is an INDIE film and only had a budget of only $250,000. That being said I feel that this was by far one of the best movies I've seen in quite some time. To me, the special effects were well done and executed. The music in the movie is what kept it all together for me though, sort of transient house music or something. It seems slow at first (or confusing), but does pick up after about the first 20 mins. The director really leaves a lot of the connections to be made by the viewer, which I liked, we don't need everything spelled out for us ALL the time in the movies. After watching this with my wife we both talked about it and had two completely different takes on "what it all meant". That rarely happens with the dribble that Hollywood has been putting out for the last few years. I would definitely recommend renting it or streaming it on the flix.

I loved it.  It's a great movie and it's good to see a small film like this rise to the top.  I would like to see more by the same people.  Don't listen to the 1-star reviewers, make up your own mind!

The rare film where both the visual effects and the actors' performances are inspired, "Ink" creates a richly textured fantasy world populated with a mixture of evocatively real and deliciously bizarre characters. Despite the somewhat flimsy premise of an afterlife where the dead influence the living through dreams - good guys, good dreams; bad guys, bad dreams - the storyline is otherwise original and compelling.  Ink, the title character, a tortured and scarred monstrosity, in an act of desperation, tears a child's spirit from her sleeping body as an offering to a clutch of ingeniously imagined incubi in exchange for promised oblivion. Arrayed against this plan is a crew of disparate spirits, loosely lead by the lovely and enigmatic Storyteller (Jessica Duffy). The captured child, Emma, is not your average victim; she is a self-possessed and resourceful little girl who controls her fears and never truly surrenders to her captor. The young actress who plays Emma, Quinn Hunchar, is talented beyond her years and somehow manages to be little-girlishly charming without being cloying cute. The actor who plays Emma's father, Chris Kelly, does a superb job of portraying all the depth and subtlety of a success-poisoned lost soul tormented by insecurity and guilt.

This independently produced film is a low-budget, high-talent, labor of love that deserves a wide viewing.

Ink proves it will always be the story that really counts! Big-budget flash and bang will never replace what this movie offers. The enthralling magic of tales woven by a master storyteller is revived in the unfolding of Ink's moving plot. It drew me in, to the point that I truly cared about every character. That's what I always hope for, but seldom find. Ink has taken a rare place as one of my all-time favorite movies. If major movie-makers began to care as much for storyline as those who made Ink obviously did, they would usher in a Golden Age of cenematic wonder.

Others have mentioned that the acting is soft in places, but I found that the comedic relief interjected well at a number of these brief moments and all was forgiven and forgotten.

The last similar movie that even comes close to the level of emotional engagement I experienced with Ink was The Iron Giant, and while The Iron Giant holds a special place in my personal movie history (and it has a robot), I am beginning to wonder if Ink has surpassed it.

Spectacular on a number of levels, and even more so when you consider that it was made with very limited funding. You owe it to the future of film to buy this movie.

I will not rehash the positive feedback that others have said. However, I will say this: Ink is an amazing movie. We watched the movie on Netflix and it captivated the attention of my whole family, a feat that is hard to accomplish. Unlike most movies, nobody talked during the entire movie. Moreover, we have watched it three times and will most likely buy it.
One of the best scifi/fantasy films produced in years.  Pan's Labyrinth wishes it was this film.

I am a jaded and cynical movie watcher, but when this movie ended, I stood up (alone in my living room) and cheered. This is, hands-down, the best new movie in years. The trailers don't do it justice at all:  this is an original, thoughtful, brilliant film.  It's a modest-budget indie, so the visuals aren't going to "blow you away" -- but they don't have to.  The story, the characters, the editing, and the haunting soundtrack, all add up to one of the best films I've ever seen.  You have to see this!  (p.s.  if you have Netflix or Blockbuster streaming, you can see it right now.)

brilliant, poetic, original, amazing, beautiful - this is a keeper! In the beginning it seems like there's all sorts of things happening that may seem random or separate. But this movie ties everything together and is shot so beautifully. It's about good and evil...about how humans are flawed, about shame, guilt, greed, love, redemption. love it love it love!

There, I said it. I can already hear the squeals of protest, but ... think about it.

The only reason viewers may even object to this characterization is that, for all its complaints about Christianity, our culture has already been so Christianized that we think the values we cheer in this movie are "normal" or "universal."

A fantastical and moving look at spiritual warfare, idolatry and what's important in life. There's even a Christ-figure for good measure. I'm not saying that's the moviemakers' intent, but I am saying that's what they produced :D despite some "language." I'm serious, I would recommend showing this to any 13+ Sunday School class for intense discusssion.

P.S. You don't have to be a Christian to enjoy this movie. It's got interesting visuals, interesting ideas, and is generally done well. But some of the parallels are too strong to ignore. However, don't worry that you or your little ones will somehow be "converted" by it. As I said, the themes in it are now pretty much part of our culture.

I give this 4 stars out of 5 only for the initial, admittedly slow beginning. But once it picks up, this is an amazing movie.

Without being too spoilerish, there are so many layers going on here that, while completely entwined to the viewer, are thus kept almost entirely separate from the characters involved in the story. Each thread could almost work on its own as a whole story (up until the end where it all fits together), but running parallel as they do they artfully reverberate off each other, making an extremely rich narrative.

Another thing I loved about this movie is how in most cases, not *everything* is explained. Certainly, there are necessary pieces of exposition, but in most cases they are expressed necessarily in simple terms a child can understand (you'll see what I mean), allowing for a broad interpretation and allowing the audience to fill-in the blanks of this "universe" as they see fit; showing not telling.

As a side comment: I commented to my friend that this story and its character archetypes could easily be translated into the core book for a role-playing game. Fellow gamers who see this might agree with me.

Yes, the acting in some cases isn't as polished as a mainline production, but the main characters are portrayed very strongly and memorably. The visuals, editing, and overall production of the film is above par for many independent productions of this type, and (imo) many big-budget Hollywood films.

Part of me hopes for a sequel; a bigger part of me would like for it to stand on its own. Either way, it's definitely worth a look.

Easily one of the best films I've seen in a while, and certainly this year. Why this film didn't or doesn't get more exposure is beyond me. Visually compelling and an original story line. It starts out kind of confusing I admit, but its worth hanging with, you'll get whats going on.. worth it for me just for the cinematography.

Ink (2009) is a climax of audio and visual stimulation that takes you on a journey of the subconsciousness. The dark and light forces fight over the soul in a thrilling and thought provoking metaphysical world that is linked to the physical one. This science fiction fantasy is packed with action between mesmerizing sequences of relaxation and happiness that offset the dark and uneasy world of the Incubi. The Incubi give nightmares while the Storytellers offer dreams of hope. These two groups battle for Emma (Quinn Hunchar) in this alternate realm, where time runs differently, as she lays in a coma in the real world after Ink took her essence to prove his worthiness to become an Incubi. Her only hope is for the Storytellers to change the path of her father, John (Chris Kelly). A series of events changed John from a loving and caring person to a deeply hurt and broken man. With the quest to change John underway another Storyteller, Liev (Jessica Duffy), attempts to adjust Ink's thinking to not continue following the path he is on. 8 out of 10 - A strait forward and simple tale this is not; it is open to some interpretation making the film difficult to follow at times. It does come together more as the film advances, but in the end it may take some nonlinear thinking to understand. Still, this is a very interesting and mind blowing film that intrigues your senses and perception. The acting was fitting for the film, but could be considered a little flat. Jamin Winans, Kiowa K. Winans, and Jeff Pointer created this unique and intriguing story. Dain Binder Dain's Movie Reviews

Though this movie is wonderful, if you order it here and now, even if you are to choose 2 day shipping and pay for that option, you will not see your movie until late november/early december. so don't even bother. and when you call to say that you don't think you should be charged for the promised earlier shipping date, you will be transferred to an individual in another country who can barely speak english. very frustrating. so although i give the movie five stars,  give amazon's service negative stars.

This film blends everything that is perfect about the scifi/fantasy genre. Everything about this film is so unique and beatiful- from the captivating story and cinematography to the film score. It's hard to believe this movie started out with no budget.

The film is about two forces agianst each other, as typical with many movies, good vs evil, the forces of light vs the incubi respectively. The forces of light give the world good dreams, while the incubi give nightmares. One day a girl is kidnapped by a mysterious evil named Ink, and the forces of light must go after her, as her father wallows away in depression.

Every frame in this movie is astounding on a visual level. The best part is really the color scheme and overtones. The colors of the movie represent all the different emotions the characters experience. Sepia represents peacefulness/happiness, darkness is dark blue/green, etc... The performances are strong, and the action is mind blowing. The dark look and tone of this film is something very special. Chris Kelly is wonderful as the father in this film. There's an extra on the dvd where he's interviewing the actress who plays the little girl which is very touching.

The only flaw with this film is there is one scene where the dialogue makes me cringe, specifically between one of the heroes and the pathfinder. But luckily it's only 1 minute of the film.

This movie is not for everyone. It's for the crowd that enjoy a lot of style and weird pacing. It has a good story, and it will definitely go over well with a mix between the Donnie Darko/Dark City crowd. This is one of my favorite films. In my opinion it's a lot better than Donnie Darko, which is another movie I enjoy, but feel it lacks a good twist. This movie is not so about a twist, but telling a compelling story which keeps the movie goer interested. It suceeds on this level. Some may find there are surprising momemts though.

*A quick thing to note is that I found out about this from the Franklyn page on amazon. This movie is much better than that one, but I still enjoy that one. Apparently this has been downloaded 400000 times in the past few days.

I really enjoyed this movie for many reasons. First, it has a story that makes you think and ask questions about life and reality. I honestly did not notice that it was an independent film. The direction was amazing and the film techniques used are visually stunning. The actors did an impressive job as well. I rarely post reviews but I was horrified to see a couple people writing bad reviews. Anyone who appreciates art films and likes movies that make you think, you will love this film. I highly recommend seeing it and will watch it several more times myself.

Got to watch for 'free' with my Amazon Prime and still one of the worst movies I've ever seen.  Too many cringe-worthy moments.  Audience too ham-fistedly told what to think about the characters.  I could tell where this was headed from the opening scenes.  I felt embarrassed for the actors; poor folk must've really needed the money bad.  The whole neo-fantasy drama playing out within a modern metropolitan backdrop is so played out!  What a pile!
This is a must-see film if you like anime, or The Crow, or Jacob's Ladder, to splatter across several genres.  A wonderful, new mythos is the backdrop for a charming story of struggle for redemption.

I'm a guy who likes Payback, the Crow, Braveheart, Nightbreed, the Empire Strikes Back, Jacob's Ladder the Outlaw Josey Wales as some of my other top favourites. Somehow, this low budget film of unknown actors became my favourite film of all time. I'm a white male who will openly confess my Christianity to the world and I don't see the "liberal bias" the naysayers are prescribing to this movie. I don't understand why this movie challenges their masculinity and makes them think it's part of some agenda. They are completely missing the point of the movie if they're focusing on a few small details to fit their own mindset. It's a great story of redemption and I'm sorry that some people got offended that the first three words are F-bombs. Yeah, the main character is facing a lot of inner demons and has some rough things happen in his life. Some are self-imposed mistakes that imperfect human beings can make and the other being the kind of tragic events that can sink the best of people. It's a movie about redemption and fighting your own darkness. There are very few movies that can make me cry and I'm talking the Brian's Song type movies that will make the toughest of men get a little misty eyed and the ending of this movie has had tears streaming down my face. I've only seen the main actor in two other movies and he's always given a good performance, but I just relate to this character more than I'd like to admit. I first watched a movie on Amazon Prime, but I quickly bought it on Blu-ray to show my support for this kind of filmmaking. I've seen the director's other movie the Frame and this director has made me a fan out of just two films. Don't just take the word of the negative reviews and actually watch it with an open mind to make your own decisions. The guy writing this review is someone who loves the Evil Dead series and watches everything from Jean-Claude Van Damme movies to Jean-Pierre Juenet artsy type films. Just watch it and make your own decision. I watch it almost once a month.

This is what film should be.  Visually stunning, mysterious, character driven amalgamation of genres to a complex cohesive conclussion. Blown away!  Should definately of heard of the director by now but for some reason not.  Hope he can make another wonderful story for us to enjoy.  Would love another wonderous adventure!

Ink is a fantastic movie, period!  The writing, directing, acting...everything is very well done.  The tension and emotion it captures is great.  As others have said, this isn't a background movie, it's a dim the lights and get lost in the story, which is very powerful :)

This was an incredible, unexpected recommended buy from Amazon. It popped up while I was browsing other movies and I almost never impulse buy, especially on the internet, but it sounded interesting and it remains to this day one of the most treasured purchases I've ever made. It's a one-of-a-kind, imaginative little indie project with highly-effective visuals and smart story-telling that I show off to friends and recommend all the time with the most immediate, common consensus being that they've never seen anything like it and they're so glad they got to experience it.

No matter how many times I watch this movie, it still brings a tear to my eye.  Ink acknowledging "I am ruined, why can't you see that" and what happens afterwards, I can't believe many people (men and women) don't have similar moments in their lives like that, and can only pray for the redemption offered through the storyteller.
Probably my all time favorite movie.  Very cerebral.  Beautiful in so many ways - morally uplifting, emotionally impacting, thought provoking.
Entertaining, though a bit ackward in parts - plays like a "first effort" by this director
Different. Critic is still out for this one.
